description:
The xianjiang noodles (E1) are legit. Has that sesame, peanut taste, mmm. We also got the beancurd noodles and dumplings (egg and chive). Both were good, but the noodles were the standout. 

Many people order the xianjiang chicken that comes in a larger wok-esque dish. Looks like it has some heat. Also, the pork and chives dumplings are popular. A staff lady was making a lot of those in back. 

Shandong Deluxe is a neighborhood spot that attracts many Chinese customers. Legit. My friend who grew up in the area told me about this place.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Really enjoyed the food. The steamed dumplings were tasty, and the wrappers were this and sturdy without being tough it rubbery.
The dry fried chicken wings were kinda wet, but very good. We asked for them not to be spicy, and a little sweet, and bang, very delicious.
We walked in and received our big take out order promptly.
I think you'll like it here.
author: Hal S.

description:
Despite the similar name to the other Shandong in Oakland I don't think their affiliated both in name and supposed quality. 

I'm not one to place emphasis on service before food quality but there is some truth to the bad service I read in other reviews. The staff is mostly non -english speaking. Mandarin is the main language spoken here and unless they you speak their tongue it's really hard to communicate with them. When I came here there was no line and we should of been the first on the list. Due to their disorganisation they didn't cross the names before us and so they kept looking for them. When people started coming they seated parties who came after us cause they were Mandarin speaking. 


Anyway we finally got seated and we ordered mapo tofu, Xianjian noodle, and beef pancake. Out of all 3 the pancake came out decent. The chicken and veggies in the Xian noodles came out tasting slightly raw and tasted like they could of Cooked it more. The mapo tofo had a strong herb taste to it. I've had mapo tofu at other restaurants and it tasted light, buttery smooth, and pleasant to eat not tangy like this one. 


All in all don't see myself coming back here since the food is rather mediocre and house of pancakes is across the street and has much better service and food by far than Shandong Deluxe.
author: Jude N.

description:
Delicious and not for the faint of heart. There's a language barrier with most of the workers so menu is helpful. and the menu doesn't include the name of the establishment so I was confused when I got in.

Ordered the xianjiang chicken. And handmade noodles. Beware of oil splattering to get to the noodle goodness. My shirt is ruined. I had to awkwardly ask for a fork. Basically it was he expensive thing on the menu and it comes out in this big wok of a thing.

Beef wrap: I pointed to the chive pancake but the server said no and to order this and said delicious delicious (yes twice) complete with thumbs up. And she wasn't lying. Crispy, savory, and yummy crepe with onions chives and beef. Add some of the spicy orange sauce and you're set. I could have just eaten an order of this and be set. Seriously. Omg delicious.

Watermelon juice. It was okay. Basically just juice a watermelon and voila. Definitely had mouth weird feels from the numbing peppers. Would have like there to be ice cubes in it.

Place is rather tiny. Restroom is at the very back of the restaurant....you have to bypass workers eating on top of refrigerators. Came on Sunday at 12....so yes...long line outside. Be prepared.
author: John Michael R.

description:
I have found memories of coming here during my high school years half a decade ago as I used to consider this the best chinese noodle place in the area. Having been to a lot more places since then, i hate to say it, but this had a few too many issues compared to other chinese noodles places in the area. Some of the dishes are reasonable, but there are a lot of misses as well. The noodles and dumplings are probably worth checking out if you're in the area, so this could be worth it if you dont get the other stuff and are willing to put up with poor service. 

Pork and mustard green noodle soup - 4/5. After all these years, at least the noodles are still good quality. A little too soft for my liking, but still pretty chewy and springy like I remember it back in the day. The pork was nice and soft, but any other flavoring the soup had was masked by how much salt they put into the soup. This made the soup and flavors feel very one note, which was disappointing. I do think the noodles are solid though, so this gets a reasonable rating regardless since I love noodles.

Pork and cabbage dumplings - 4/5. Juicy and on point despite being a bit salty. Similar to how my mom makes them, which makes this pretty authentic.

Lamb skewers - 2.5/5. Texture was okay, but it came to the table lukewarm... the spices were also didnt have much flavor to it, which is very different from the skewers youd get in china.

Cabbage/shrimp thing - 2/5. Parents insisted we get this, but wasnt a huge fan. All I could really taste here was cabbage and salt, but I suppose I don't really like shrimp to begin with.

Fried green onion pancake- 2.5/5. Flavor was okay, but this literally fell apart as we were eating it, which I didnt think could happen with green onion pancake... (in not a good way) this was also on the softer side rather than the crispy side, which is more of a preference.

Tea - 2/5. I dont normally bring up the tea since it's fairly standard, but it was lukewarm when it arrived to our table.
author: Nevin L.

description:
If you're Asian and don't speak Mandarin well, don't come here, and don't even try calling in for takeout orders. Just because I chose not to speak Mandarin to order my food, that doesn't mean I don't understand the trashtalk the male server will laugh about right in front of you with other workers. Oh, and don't assume I didn't understand you when you called me Vietnamese trash. 我不想跟你用中文來溝通，是錯事嗎？(Translation: I didn't want to speak Chinese to communicate with you, is that so wrong?) 

Oh but if you're Caucasian White or any other color-skinned person, you're fine. They're too intimidated by their own broken English ability to say much to your face anyway. 

This visit was nothing but pure discriminatory actions. They overcooked our food, forgot about it even. We came in before the dinner rush, and they waited until more people started coming in, took THEIR orders first even though WE waved them over, and didn't even bother to apologize. The dumplings were soggy and broke apart easily. Too gelatinous in texture too. It felt like I was eating jello with a salty filling.
author: Elaine L.

description: This is the place where all the Chinese come for some authentic Chinese dumplings and hand made noodles. Great selections and service is pretty good. The two ladies who work the front are very nice, one is especially good with kids. Owner must be getting some good deals on salt, most of their cold appetizers are on the salty side but very tasty. Highly recommend the pork dumplings with napa cabbage, fish dumplings and beef dumplings. On the noodle side, we like the beef noodle soup and spicy pork noodles.
author: William C.

description: Their noodle soup is da bomb!  Tried their beef tendon and lamb noodle soups, xiaolungbao (steam dumplings), and egg pancake wraps.. all are very tasty!  Better yet, I don't think they put msgs (at least not much) in the food, cuz, I don't feel thirsty after the meal...
author: Howie L.

description:
Happened upon here by accident. The wait at House of Pancakes was 5 parties deep and 30 - 45 minutes, saw that this place was known for their hand-pulled noodles and decided to try it out.

The restaurant is pretty old school Chinese, so don't expect super attentive and warm service. I ordered the spicy beef noodle stew and garlic green beans. The noodles themselves were very good--you could tell by the texture and consistency that they were hand pulled and fresh. The beef was okay, tender but without a ton of flavor. The broth and soup were a letdown. You could tell the spicy flavor came from a sauce that was just dumped in to spice up the soup. This flavor completely overpowered the rest of the broth and even made it taste slightly sour, which is not how a Chinese beef noodle stew is supposed to taste.

The garlic green beans were very good. Overall, this place is cheap and the noodles are good. Maybe another noodle dish would've been better. I also saw a lot of people ordering dumplings and buns, which might be better options as well.
author: Tim X.

description: Was walking by and noticed they specialize in hand pulled noodles. Ducked in for takeout mid afternoon. The hand pulled noodles were awesome. Decent dumplings and pork buns. While we waited for our order were served complimentary tea. Nice touch.
author: Joe M.

description:
Very authentic little Chinese restaurant (read: bring cash, only venture to order if you speak Mandarin, and don't expect ice water the first time you ask for it) that the fiance and I happened upon because I was craving hand pulled noodles. 

We got the xinjiang noodle with chicken (we were actually trying to order the xinjiang chicken since other people raved about it, but apparently my Mandarin was not up to par) and pork and napa dumplings. I wasn't a fan of the noodle dish--the noodles themselves were handmade and chewy just the way I like them, but the dish was very oily and relatively flavorless, except a tingly/numbing aftertaste that worsened with each bite. The dumplings, though, were plump and juicy with a nice chewy wrapping, and apparently you can buy them premade and frozen to go! I think that is the only thing I would ever go back for.
author: Yang Q.

description:
Came back to this restaurant a few more times after my first review. I have to lower the rating to 3 stars because it's too inconsistent here.

Two times, the XLB's were delicious and soupy. Another two times, the XLB's were soggy no soup in them at all.

One time I was able to pay with credit card. Another time, I was asked to pay with cash instead.

The pork dumplings with napa had been good every time, but the XLB's are a hit or miss.
author: Wesley S.

description:
1. Xinjiang noodle with lamb was delicious. I enjoyed the texture. It is very elastic and has a nice relatively chewy texture, but still soft enough for you to slurp on without choking yourself. The vegetables also tasted fresh and added nice colors to the dish. The lamb was tender and tasty.

2. The chicken and corn dumplings are comforting! I could pop those into my mouth all day. The dumplings were freshly made and cooked.

3. The pan fried dumpling was delicious too. It came out very hot. It was my first time having pan fried dumpling in SF so I have nothing to compare to, but it did not disappoint. 

4. The chicken wings were sweet, juicy, and fun to eat. Definitely great for snack or appetizer.

5. The food took a while to come out and the wait can be long. We were lucky to get a table right away Friday night around 8pm. A huge group came about 10 minutes after we arrived.
author: Eileen H.

description:
First meal of 2018! My parents are a regular here and say the food is well-priced and consistent in quality. The restaurant is small but the wait is usually not more than 15 minutes when we come at our usual Sunday lunchtime. 

Shanghai steam pao (D1, $4.95) - this is their XLB, comes with six. Taste is good but they over-steamed them today, which made it difficult to lift out of the steamer without breaking them (btw - self-proclaimed chopstick pro over here). The metal steamer's bottom has a sparse lattice structure and because the XLB was cooked too long, the dumpling skin sunk into them and started sticking to them despite the paper layer underneath designed to keep this from happening. If this is how they usually cook their soup dumplings, then I wouldn't order it again...seeing all that good XLB soup escape to anywhere other than my mouth is a small tragedy.

Beef wrap (D8, $6.95) - such a great deal for a large portion of the beef wrap. My dad always orders this. Comes with a lot of onions and cilantro in it though, so just a heads up if you're not a fan. I pick all of my cilantro out lol.

Xian cold noodle (E1, $6.00) - this is awesome. Apparently the wait staff puts this dish together (not the kitchen) with a variety of sauces, so the taste each time depends on the ratio of sauces the waiter or waitress mixes for your dish. Today it was really good. It was the perfect amount of spicy to make it more flavorful without making your mouth feel like it's on fire, and there's some vinegar for a sour kick that's not overpowering. The dish comes with cold noodles, cucumber, cilantro, bean sprouts, and chopped peanuts. We mix it all together before eating. 

Comb spicy seafood, chicken, pork noodle (E7, $7.95) - this is also great, and comes in a big bowl without skimping on the meats. The seafood in here includes shrimp, octopus, and fish fillets. There are also mushrooms and red and green bell peppers. The kitchen does a great job of blending the spicy and sour flavors into the soup, and the noodles are a great bouncy texture. Def a fan of this.

Owner and wait staff are friendly, food is good, space is clean enough for this type of Chinese restaurant. This spot would have four stars from me if not for the XLB breaking all over the place. Will order it again next time and update my review accordingly.
author: Nicole M.

description:
This is my favorite noodle place is SF. All their noodles are hand pulled and their dumplings are homemade. Their noodles are super smooth and chewy. IT'S AMAZING. I love their Dan Dan noodles because their spicy soup base is so addicting!!

I didn't really like their stir fright green beans very much. It seems like they overlooked it. It didn't have the crunch that I was expecting. 

My mom loves their handmade dumplings. If you can't get enough during your visit, you can buy frozen ones to go! 

They also have great chicken wings and green onion pancakes!
author: Melody L.

description: I mainly come to this restaurant for their Xiao Long Bao. However, after exploring other dumpling restaurants, Shandong's is only average. I recommend ordering the Pork Dumpling with Chives. Its extremely delicious, and one dish gives you 12 pieces. The reason I gave a 3 star is because of the waitress' attitude. When she took my order, she did not happy and sort of rolled her eyes when I asked for a togo box. Also, it is really hard to get a hold of the waitress. She is always in the back doing something.
author: Michelle T.

description: I always enjoy coming here to eat not just because it's in my neighborhood :) My favorite dish is probably the combo seafood noodle soup because it has the right amount of spiciness and a variety of veggies and meat. I also buy their frozen dumplings because it's so convenient to just boil them at home when I'm feeling lazy. A plus is that they accept credit card because there are a few places on Taraval that are cash only. I will definitely come back again soon!
author: Kristine P.

description:
Been here over 2 dozen times; the waitress still doesn't acknowledge me, but who cares, the food is good. For some context, I've dined at nearly a dozen places that serve these same dishes (Millbrae, San Bruno, SF places). This place rates the highest for the following:

Shredded potatoes w/o peppers- tangy and vinegary, with some crisp to the potatoes, like Asian fries.
Beef wrap- crispy, large, and fresh.
Chicken/corn dumpling (though it is on par with all other places)
Pan fried pork buns- my favorite here. They are huge with tasty fillings; crispy and flavorful bun.
Cold noodle dish- peanutty with perfectly textured handmade noodles.

Most of their dishes are fantastic, but because I can't do spicy, their waitress' lack of memory results in a painful experience at times.

4.5/5
author: Ben P.

description: Fam Bam Thur Lunch! First time here. Heard their XLB and noodles are good. Now what we think. Their XLB is definitely a no! The rest is not all that but we did enjoy the pig ear. Our favorite was just the noodles. The ja jang mian noodle was pretty good. They are known for fresh made noodles which it is pretty good. Nice and chewy. Service is ok. Slow and Short staff but they are nice. 3 Star which is for the noodles , nice staff and the rest is ok.
author: Christy V.

description:
The food is pretty good at this little hole in the wall place, and excellent hand pulled noodles.
I'm giving them 2 stars for their janky service.  One of the dishes we had ordered was fried rice.  Something got lost in translation and we got some fried noodles.  Western restaurants would take the dish back and bring the right one, but the dude was urging us to keep the one they brought by mistake... after a bit of eye rolling and cursing under our breath, we told the dude we'd take the mistaken order to go and have them make the fried rice dish too.
Again had this been a western restaurant, they likely would have given us a discount.  But nope, we sucked up their mistake.
So make sure they get your order right to begin with.
author: Roni L.

description: The food is excellent and authentic.  This is what you will eat in China.  It's not a Chinese-American chop suey place.
author: Will L.

description:
My sister and I went to Shandong Deluxe for dinner on September 15, 2018. I always passed by the restaurant and was curious to try the food. We got a small table in front of the cashier. It wasn't very comfortable, but the restaurant was small. The first red flag was that the waitress used a dirty towel, which was dropped to the ground, to wipe our table. She did not even apologize and think about getting a new towel. (Other waitresses used the same dirty towel to clean other tables. This is very not hygienic!) My sister and I tried flagging down the waitress, but she refused to make eye contacts with us. Finally, she came to our table and take our orders (Shanghai Dumplings, Spicy Mopo Tofu, and Vegetable Soup Noodle). While we waited for our food, I noticed two families came inside: one family of six and one family of three. These two families got their food first before we got our first dish, which was the noodle soup. I was already irritated at this point, but I didn't want to make a big scene. My sister and I kept eating our food. Fifty minutes into eating, I was shocked we still hadn't gotten our Shanghai Dumplings! Fifty minutes. I flagged down the waitress and asked where the dumplings were. I actually asked her to cancel the order, which I rarely do when I am dining out. She came back to our table and said that the dumplings were being steamed. At this moment, I knew the waitress had forgotten our order. How long does it take to steam dumplings??? I asked her when the dumplings would be ready. She pretended she didn't understand me. She didn't even apologize for her mistake! My sister was honest and rejected the dumplings. At this moment, I noticed the two families already finished eating and left the restaurant! Unbelievable. Terrible service. Rude. Unprofessional. My sister and I did not have a good experience here. We will not come back. The food was just mediocre.  

Note for improvement: treat your customers equally even those who speak Mandarin in a different accent. We understand you when you speak in Mandarin. We notice when we are being treated differently!
author: Jessica T.

description:
Our pan fried pork dumplings were completely RAW. I felt sick after taking a bite. It wasn't even close to being cooked. It was disgusting. I don't know how it got such a good health score bc the place felt so dirty and the plates/bowls/utensils were definitely not clean.

AVOID this place! Typically I give places second chances but I don't want to risk my health.
author: J A.

description:
If i could give this place 0 or negative stars i would. Came in with 3 other people and ordered 4 dishes and waitress kept insisting that its not enough. We told her some of us ate already and she smirked at us and started talking crap about us in chinese thinking we don't understand her. 

Food here is okay (3/5). Service (-10/5). If we say we want 4 dishes, don't keep insisting we need more than what we ordered.
author: Valerie H.

description:
Ok I don't think this place is a 3-star, but maybe not a 5 star either, definitely at least 3.5-4 stars. 
quick good service of food. I asked for raw garlic (love garlic and vinegar with the dumplings) and got it for free on the side. 
the mackerel dumplings are a must-try, very authentic. hand made noodles and dumplings for sure. they did boil them to a semi-soft way instead of chewy so some people may or may not like that.
we got E7 Comb Spicy Seafood Chicken Pork noodles, B3 Fish Dumplings (spanish mackerel), fresh jelly fish salad (so good), A11 marinater pig ear, all very good and hit the spot. 
would say it is very authentic!
author: S W.

description:
Came here Saturday noon, there was a short wait in the crowded restaurant.

As soon as we sat down we were brought dirty, plates and teacups. I'm talking about a huge piece of food still stuck to the inside of the teacup. All the plates were a different design as well.

My family ordered the cold noodle thing with the sliced cucumbers on top, lamb soup, a beef onion roll and the da pan ji. The cold noodle plate was tasty but nothing fancy. The lamb soup was literally old, tough pieces of lamb in a broth of oil. The beef onion roll was more green onions than beef and the da pan ji took about 40 minutes.

Not impressed with this restaurant at all, if they're willing to crank out dirty plates and cups, I can only imagine what their kitchen looks like. The food was mediocre at best. Only thing worth trying is the hot sauce condiment.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
My family and I came here with my grandpa on a Sunday at around 11am. The restaurant was small and a little crowded, and we were seated right away. The servers spoke Mandarin, and we spoke Cantonese so communication was a little spotty, but nothing too major. The first thing I noticed when we were seated and given the plates and utensils was that the plates were not the same size. My plate size was bigger than my brother's and the inconsistency of the plate size kind of bothered me. The seating was also tight, since the tables were all close together. We ordered 6 dishes for the 6 of us.

Food:

- Xiao long bao: The xiao long bao was kind of small. It was also overcooked, since the soupy goodness came out and wasn't in the dumplings when we ate it.

- Potstickers: The potstickers were big and delicious, though it didn't have that nice crispy bottom from when you panfry them, and the skin was a little soggy.

- Green onion pancakes: There was not a lot of green onions. This pancake was thin and crispy, which I liked, but I wish there was a bit more dough in the pancakes.

- Beef tendon noodle soup: The noodle soup broth was light and not too heavy, though there wasn't much flavoring. However, the beef tendon was nice and soft and tender. The noodles were super long, and we had to ask one of the servers to come and cut it for us, since it was hard to dish the long noodles in the bowls.

- Beef chow fun: The noodles were oily and not crispy enough. There was a lot of bean sprouts (I love bean sprouts), but the ratio of beef and noodles to bean sprouts was way off, with too many bean sprouts and not enough beef and noodles.

- Garlic green beans: The green beans had enough garlic, though the green beans themselves were kind of soggy and not crispy.

Another major thing that I noticed was that when we were served the food, no serving utensils were given to us. Maybe it was kind of like "every man for themselves" and everyone was supposed to get the food with their own chopsticks, but I just wished they gave us serving utensils so it was easier to dish out the food. Overall, I'm kind of disappointed since when we walk by, we usually see a line of people out the door so I assumed the food would be good. The food was decent, but I don't think my family and I would come back here to eat.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Beef noodle soup 
Shrimp dumplings
Chow fun with shrimp

Ordered what we liked; didn't really use the menu. 

Bill came to $34 including tip. 

It felt homey and homemade and it was cute to see the rather conservative, traditional servers going gaga over my little cutie. They happily brought him his requested extra shrimp.
author: Camille L.

description: This a small hole in the wall place, it was pretty much empty when my friend and I came in at around 6. But shortly after being seated, the place quickly filled up. I got the black bean with pork noodle, it was alright, but a bit too salty for my liking. The noodles had a good semi-chewy texture and were very elastic. The flavor was strong, but as I said before was too salty. Service was okay, you might need to flag down a waiter if you really want something.
author: Donald C.

description: Hole in the wall type of place.  Not the cleanest but as with most hole in the wall places thats what you can pretty much expect coming here. XLB's are a hit or miss, they are either really soupy or soupless.. but I'm usually ok with this since I love any kind of dumpling! They could try cleaning the bottle to the vinegar sauce they provide on the table.. It feels like people touched their food with their hands and then proceeded to pick up the bottle... or it feels like food splattered on the bottle with no one wiping it down and then the whole cycle repeats itself with each new customer sitting at the table. LOL ok, my imagination is getting out of hand. Overall, I like this place because it's walking distance and very convenient.
author: Mauricia L.

description:
Let's be real for a second...legit Chinese food in the city does not equal legit service in the city. The service is spotty as hell, and the seating is awkward, but if you can get past all of that, the shanghainese food here is super legit. 

Decor - strange. Some tables seem higher than they should be for the seats. Place is super tiny, so the set-up of some of the tables are awkward as hell. 

Service - it's majorly hit or miss. There's always this one waitress there that's super jollier compared to the rest. When they're busy (bc they do a ton of take-out orders), the dine-in service decreases significantly. 

Food - . Authentic, homemade shanghainese food. Get the hand pulled noodles, homemade fish dumplings, pan fried potstickers, tofu skin side dishes, and their peanut sauce noodle (they'll def recommend this, even if you don't ask for a reco). There's also a spicy chicken dish situation that everyone always gets - I don't eat chicken, but my friends and family tell me it's legit. All in all, you really can't go wrong with any of their dishes here. 

Decor/ambiance - 3
Service - 3
Food - 6! haha

Rounds up to 4 stars, right?
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Affordable, great service and yummy food. What more can a girl ask for? This restaurant has the best orange hot sauce too. It's super spicy...but it's literally so so good with everything here!

From the menu, the highlights are their Shanghai dumplings which are perfect, with soup oozing out right after you bite the tip of the dumpling off. Add a little vinegar, their orange sauce and you're good to go. The pan fried dumplings are good as well. The spicy beef noodle soup is one of their most popular dishes, order this! My bf loves their cold noodles, which sells out pretty quick. Also their apps like bean curd salad, cucumber salad, and beef tripe are pretty addicting.

Tips:
+Noodles are house made, who doesn't love homemade noodles?!
+Super cheap! 
+Cash only, there is a BofA across the street!
author: Elisa S.

description:
Shandong Deluxe is okay, not great, but I think it's more Northern Chinese cuisine where I'm biased towards Southern Cantonese delights.

The service is friendly 'tho more ESL where it helps if you speak Mandarin Chinese, but they can and do communicate in English.

The seating is a bit cramped and the dining area space is small.

We tried their signature dish, Xinjlang Style Chicken * with noodle which was a generous portion for the price, but the spices used, and it wasn't a matter of it being hot spices, but the blend oddly had everyone at the table feel a hazy numbness in their tastebuds that was alarming and discomforting to a degree, so we ended up boxing it up to evaluate and try later.

The cut noodle used for the Xinjang dish was a broad thick chow fun styled rice noodle I think, which was very good in taste (sans the Xinjang spice sauce) and texture, which was a bit chewy.  

I'd love to know what dishes they serve using this noodle and would try it again.

Parking in the area of Taravel near 19th avenue can be easy and can be tough, it's random parking karma and timing whether you go for a meter or venture into the residential neighborhood.

With so many options to eat in San Francisco, I doubt if I'd come back here on my own accord, but if I was with a group who insisted on going here, I'd give it another try and order other menu items to try it again.
author: Rick S.

description:
Along Taraval, there's a gluttony of spots offering up noodles and dumplings. I'm pretty sure I've been to at least a third of them now and to me, none of them have stood out from the rest. I was pretty excited to try Shandong Deluxe as I had already missed an opportunity to do so many moons ago. Let me tell you this; go earlier than traditional lunch time noon hours as you'll be waiting if your party is greater than 2. It got packed quick but luckily I was smugly sitting my table already.  

They have a semi open kitchen and you can see them cooking up food and putting it on the counter for the wait staff to bring it out. We started with the fish filets in spicy chili oil and it was presented in Paul Bunyan's soup cup. Tons of Sichuan peppers and fresh peppercorns provided a kick but it wasn't overwhelming. I wish their had been more fish than vegetables though. We also got their seafood and meat combo noodles that I thought would be stir-fried but instead came with some odd looking tomato like broth. Not bad but not great either.  The dumplings, which were pan fried but can be steamed, were humongous. It reminded me of the Vietnamese banh bao in terms of girth and dough to filling ratio. I had one and it was delicious with their home made hot sauce. I would recommend skipping the beef roll pancake though. Too much hoisin and not enough flavors of beef.

I'm big on having competition for most things in life, with food being my most passionate to date. It gives me an excuse to continue looking for the best since this was only 3 stars for me.
author: Quoc N.

description: Service was horrible, I asked for ice water three times it took 10 minute for it to get here when the water came there are weird particles floating all over there was also a tiny chunk of something inside. I asked the waitress to please replace it for me , she took the water and I never got it back not even after paying the bill.........food was not good don't think I will be returning...
author: Kimco L.

description: Horrific AND slow service. Food is extremely basic, you could get it anywhere. Definitely go somewhere else unless you want a shitty waitress that's rude and forgets your order.
author: Carol Y.

description: Such a hit or miss. Got the spicy beef noodle soup last night, expecting that robust smoky flavor from chili oil and what not. To my disappointment, it was just regular beef noodle soup with a dallop of their orange hot sauce mixed into it... Meh. I just asked for a plate of chili oil on the side and mixed it into the soup myself. Beef roll was pretty good last night as always. As well as the chive pork dumplings. Both are staple orders. Will be an average 3 stars.
author: Susanna C.

description: Ordered 3 plates Togo, 2 of the 3 were wrong! The waiteress completely ignored me, I stood there waiting for her to serve me, but she kept looking at the bills for other customers dining in the restaurant. Finally I had to flag down another waitress who helped me. I would rate it 0 stats if it was an option.
author: Silver Y.

description:
Came here on a Sunday at 7. Surprisingly it was not busy. I pass by a lot and see a wait. 

I got the xian cold noodles, spicy tendon, beef rolls, xlb and cold bean noodle. The Xian cold noodles were not good. They tasted a bit like watered down peanut sauce plus a little vinegar. Beef rolls had a little too much vegetables and too little meat. XLB was good. Spicy tendon was good, not too spicy though. Cold bean noodle was probably my favorite.

Pictures on yelp are pretty consistent. I would come back if I wanted some XLB.
author: Darlene T.

description:
Chicken and noodles (大盘鸡) was excellent, not too spicy, but just the enough amount of spices. Great price for the portion too, $20 feed 2 -3 people.
Recommend this dish!
author: X G.

description: Went on a busy Saturday during lunch hours. The Big Plate Chicken was spicy and delicious. The lamb soup with bread pieces didn't have a single piece of lamb.
author: Justin L.

description:
Shandong's hand-cranked noodles and dumplings seem quite authentic. The restaurant is very simple in appearance and casual thus, they produce reasonable foods at a low cost.

At $7.95 their Lamb Dumpling w/Squash (11) come somewhat like a soup dumpling, filled with juice/broth, meat and vegetable. 

At $7.95 their (4) Lamb Skewers appetizer looks spicy but it is not. It is very well seasoned yet its lamb-ness remains intact.

At $5.95 the Marinated Pork Elbow Salad (cold) was just too plain for me yet may speak volumes to you.

In the specialty dim sums section of the menu they offer a $6.95 Beef Wrap. Although there may be more veggie than meat this was quite heavy/filling.

Not for everyone but I do enjoy the $6.95 Napa (cabbage) w/dry shrimp.
author: Caesar A.

description:
I saw a lot of bad reviews for this place but I guess it really depends on what you order. This place is known for their noodles as they are handmade and pretty authentic. 

Recommended dish: 新疆丁丁炒面. Delicious chopped up noodles with various vegetables and beef.
author: Tom P.

description:
i love this place.
i don't think there's ever been a dish ordered that i've hated. 
the vibe is casual, as in you can come here wearing sweats and sandals, no big deal.
i think their specialty is the dapanji aka big chicken dish. its the priciest thing under "noodles." NOTE if you get this, expect to wait a while maybe like 20-30 minutes? the wait will be worth it.
my all time favorite though is the cold noodles and spicy boiled fish fillet. i dont know what they put in the spicy soup but it's amazing. i never finish the broth but i always take it home so that i can add in my own fish for leftovers.
as for the cold noodles, if you don't come early they will probably sell out. 

things here are very spicy and a lot of their dishes have those numbing peppercorns, so be careful! but i love it, and maybe you will too.
author: Rily S.

description: The Xi'an Cold noodle is the best for sure. Dumplings are highly recommended also. Actually the food there are awesome.
author: Ming S.

description: I can't put into words how good the food here is.  I came here with a friend on a rainy day and we split a few noodle & dumpling soups.  It was sublimely good.  I've honestly never had better noodles.  Maybe not the best place to go if you're in a hurry but it's worth making time for.
author: Patrick C.

description: I am pleasantly surprised to be a fan of this neighborhood Sunset spot. First off, the XLB had a good skin but most importantly had a very flavorful soup inside. They all remained intact as we picked them out of the steamer...another plus. We tried the Xinjian noodles and I couldn't stop eating it. Loved the  texture of theses wide, cold, flat noodles and the sauce was addictive. They have an assortment of other dumplings with various insides. I'd definitely come back to try more things on their menu, especially the Xinjiang chicken noodle dish that I saw several tables order.
author: Rick T.

description: I can only comment on the frozen vegetarian dumplings which are great to keep at home for a lazy meal.  Make sure to get the "chive and egg" dumpling instead of the "vegetarian" dumplings, which has a cabbage mixture which has been chopped a bit too finely with not much texture.  The chive filling is more flavorful and also vegetarian.  The texture of the dumpling skin is nice and chewy, not too thick or thin.  I believe it is around $8 for a bag of 20. Credit card is for minimum of $20.  The noodle dishes also look good, hopefully I can try them in the future.
author: Susan W.

description:
Came here for a late lunch. The place is pretty small so it might be hard getting a table during the lunch rush.

We ordered a large variety if dishes: vegetable dumpling, chive pancake, spicy noodles, bean curd, spicy potatoes,  fungus with cucumber salad. The chives pancake and vegetable dumpling were delicious.

The tea here was light on flavor. And similar with other Asian restaurants, you need to constantly flag the server to get anything. But it's definitely worth it for the food.
author: Goku U.

description:
Every good restaurant will do something a little bit different or better than their competition. For Shandong Deluxe, their forte is the handmade noodles and it's something I keep coming back for.

I first tried this place on a whim about two years ago and was instantly hooked on their spicy beef noodle soup, more specifically their delicious noodles found in said soup. When picking up the noodles, I always notice how each strand is strikingly different. The imperfections from hand pulling creates a variety of thin and thick noodles that provide a nice contrast in textures and gives each bite a unique mouthfeel. I've had this dish elsewhere and their noodles are always identical, and uniformity is boring. The broth is also very flavorful, with a good balance between spicy and savory.

I always order a few items when I come here and that's so I can see what goes well with the spicy beef noodle soup. While the dumplings aren't the best I've had, they are a great side to compliment the main course. For pairing, I recommend the pork with napa cabbage or chicken with corn as the subtle sweetness from the cabbage and corn goes well with the spicy broth. Their beef pancake and pan fried buns are okay, but the former is a bit too greasy and the latter is too doughy for my liking. Maybe I'll try dipping them in the soup next time, I'll have to report back. For about $9, it's hard to beat a bowl of soup with delicious handmade noodles. Give it a try!
author: Philip W.

description:
Came here for an early quick bite.  Inexpensive fare and the noodle soup was just light enough to be refreshing (some may call it bland).
I'd give it a 3.5-4.

Hand pulled noodles were good.
Yellow stained old plastic bowls were bad.   Time to switch to glass bowls or replace them pronto.

Restroom was clean on this visit, and you get a chance to walk by the open kitchen and see them pulling noodles and making dim sum near the fridge at the back.
author: Drew B.

description: I ordered the spicy beef noodle and vegetable shrimp dumplings. The noodles were chewy. However, both noodles and dumplings were SUPER SALTY. I can't finish either of these, I ended up bring home and used hot water to wash out the salty taste. I will not go here anymore.
author: Jenny M.

description: Come here for the noodles not the service. The service definitely leaves little to be desired but the hand-pulled noodles are simply delicious. I got the spicy beef noodle soup. It was spicy but I couldn't stop eating because it was so good! I would come back to try all the other noodle dishes.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Very DISAPPOINT !! Has been to this place since it open, and usually order frozen dumpling to go. But the quality is getting worse now, I find the broken bones in the lamp dumpling, ALL of it! Every single bite! The hardness could cause tooth wear, so you can image how hard that is, that will cause serious problem if old people eat it!!!! If they continue the irresponsibility attitude when they making food for people then i don't think we will go back again! 

非常失望！從開業就常光顧，每次都會點冷凍水餃帶走，可是現在的質量變的非常不好，每一次都會點的羊肉水餃，現在在裡面竟然吃到了碎掉的骨頭，每一塊裡面都有，而且非常硬，不知道的人很容易咬下去很容易傷到牙齒，特別是老人家吃的話會很危險！我認為這種對食物這麼不負責任不細心的態度讓人很生氣！如果再持續這樣，我不認為我們還會去消費！
author: Ni K.

description: Fake commercial, cold food, junky service. We came because of their ads said 80 percents off now, but they admit that and charge me full price. I heard the owner talk to her staff "ads is just the ads, I would not giving up even 1 cent"
author: Wen W.

description:
Very disappointed!! The quality is getting worse and worse. Dumping not as fresh as usual. The beef rolls taste like....you know the rest~ I won't come any mores

真的不好吃, 水餃不新鮮, 牛肉捲餅太難吃了~
author: Jerry Y.

description: 2/2.5 stars; food was alright. It was a decent experience to try Northern Chinese cuisine, but the wait was ridiculous. Not only is this place quite busy at night, the seating is very limited and cramped. After waiting for a long while, they told us (3 adults) to sit on a tiny two-seater (small table) that was awkwardly placed in between tables and the turning corner. Since there wasnt enough table space, we decided to wait a bit longer for a bigger table to clear. When our dumplings came, I squeezed the soy sauce bottle to find a small dead bug on my plate. Overall, it was nice to try, but will probably not return.
author: Joanne H.

description:
This is a fairly busy small restaurant. Warning, don't expect to be waited on, you need to figure out what you want and wave down the wait staff. The house chicken dish is a must try, but order additional homemade hand pulled noodles.  Bring lots of friends, this will easily feed six people.  Their dumplings are all good, so definitely try anyone of them.  If you expect the wait staff to fawn over you, this is not the place for you, this is a busy hole in the wall fantastic place to eat and you don't need to come here wasting the  wait staffs time or mine i'm waiting behind you when you are clueless.
Great restaurant but just order anything, I have not ordered anything that i have not liked here.
author: Raymond L.

description:
My friend's mom took me here on my last day in SF. It's one of her favorites for authentic Chinese food, which SF does wonderfully.

Apparently later on in the day it gets really crowded, but thankfully we got there early on a rainy day, which meant no lines for us! We were seated an took a while to decide what we wanted to eat. Another bonus about eating here, besides the fact that the food is delicious is the price! In comparison to the $22 brunch I had the day before, it was refreshing to see generous portions in the $5-10 range. The food comes out relatively quickly too!

COLD NOODLES: These cold noodles were different than ones I've had before. The noodles are flat and larger, and the sauce is less thick. Nonetheless, this was one of my favorite things we ordered! I love the sauce and the cucumbers that top it all off. 
PORK AND CHIVE DUMPLINGS: Towards the back of the restaurant sits a lovely woman who hand makes all of the dumplings. I love that! The meat was really well seasoned and the dumplings were nice and soupy! For around $6 (or more for other meats, less for veggies) you get 20 dumplings, which is a steal!
LAMB SKEWERS: This dish came with 4 skewers that each had about 4-5 pieces of lamb on them. They were sprinkled with cumin and some spicy red pepper seasoning. I'm not the biggest fan of lamb, but I thought this one offered a different flavor from the rest of the things we ordered. 

I can only imagine how good everything else on the menu is! Come around 11 to avoid the line and taste great Chinese food!
author: Jayleen Y.

description:
My mom and I love coming here for authentic Chinese food. Common with most Asian restaurants, though the service may not be the fastest, the food is delicious. And it is super cheap. You get huge portions at low prices. Here are some of the more notable dishes they serve here. They are known for the noodles (you can see the chefs make it fresh in the back from your seat).

COLD NOODLES - This was a very interesting dish. It is flat rice noodles topped with peanut sauce and cucumbers. I recommend this as an appetizer. I can't quite pinpoint what the flavor is but it is unique and a must-try. 

DUMPLINGS - Dumplings here tend to have a thick skin. My favorite is the chicken and corn. They also have unique flavors like lamb or sea cucumber. 

ZHA JIANG MEIN - This is the absolute best. It is noodles topped with a black bean paste. It isn't too salty. It may look ugly but this is hands down the most popular dish here.

LAMB SKEWERS - This is also seasoned with a unique flavor that compliments the lamb well. However, this has more of a Western flavor to it and is not traditional Chinese food (if that is what you are looking for).
author: Melinda L.

description:
3rd time here with friends.

I ordered Spicy Beef Noodle Soup.
Hand made Noodle is great and chewy 
Beef is very soft 
Soup is not that good. Too spicy!

So here is the problem, they have a open kitchen 
I happen to see their chef took his big spoon and drink out of that spoon and put it right back in the pot. 
I am sure many chef does that but problem is they shouldn't have their customer see it! "Open kit
author: Mack A.

description:
We ordered two beef tendon noodle soups, beef stew noodle soup, dumplings, beef wrap, lamb skewer, beef pan cake, and red bean paste cake. 

We were seated soon after we arrived and the food came out quickly. Service was good as we got what we needed quickly. 

Let's review the food items we ordered. The red bean paste cake was baked instead of fried. That made me think they bought it from a supermarket. The beef pan cake was not crispy and the inside was not juicy.  The dumplings I couldn't taste the meat but I can taste the salt. The beef wrap didn't have much beef in it and over sauced and had too much cilantro. It's call a beef wrap and not cilantro wrap. The noodle soups only had five to six small pieces of stew and tendons in each bowl. My son loves beef tendons and he didn't touch any of his in his bowl. The noodles were good and were plentiful.  The lamb skewer was very good.  Should have ordered nine lamb skewers instead. 

We won't be back again.
author: Eric L.

description: Went there around 5pm on Sunday.  Ordered the Shandong chicken Noodle.   Had to wait 45 minutes to get it.  Food taste = 7/10.   That dish is for 3-4 people because it is HUGE.   Will come back again to try others
author: Stanley L.

description:
Didn't have a great experience at Shandong Deluxe. Came here for lunch with my family on a Saturday afternoon. We ordered a few items to share:

- Pork Dumpling with Chives: great portion, okay texture, but the pork tasted bland.
- Xiao Long Bao: six dumplings, but the skin tore apart very easily, causing the soup to leak out. Not particularly memorable.
- Chicken chow mein: they used their own hand pulled noodles, which was very interesting. But the dish was incredibly greasy, and the chicken was very rough and had a strange taste.
- Pork & Fungus Noodle: not that great -- noodle and soup were extremely bland, some ingredients used were very salty, egg had a strange taste.

Overall, I was quite disappointed by the quality of the food.
author: Alvin W.

description: They changed their chef and the food is not as good as it used to be. I used to get takeout from this place all the time, but the last time I called, they told me they didn't speak English and hung up on me. Pretty bummed to see the food quality and service go down the past few months.
author: Jules C.

description: I have to agree with the review of "S W." from Orange, CA...  Shandong Deluxe is NOT a 3-star establishment.  I would give this establishment "4-4.5 stars" based on the fact that it's menu is filled with dishes I'd never even heard of, the pricing is reasonable, and I've loved everything I've eaten.  I stumbled into this place accidentally and have now become a full blown regular.  If you want reasonably priced authentic Asian cuisine that feels like a home-cooked meal, do yourself a favor and stop by Shandong Deluxe.
author: Marlon O.

description:
The food was not bad at all for such cheap price and huge portion, but note that the shrimp and chive dumplings were mostly chives - there's about 1/5 of a small shrimp in each dumpling. Talk about cutting cost.

Service was pretty much everybody said how it was. As my companion and I settled down at our table, neither tea or water was served to us, and the two waitress ladies were discussing in Mandarin on whether they should've got us tea. Unfortunately, we picked up a little Mandarin. Fortunately, my companion was not as petty as I am.
author: Chii L.

description:
231. Stopped here for a late lunch after a visit to the zoo.  They have very limited seating, but we got here after 2pm, so it was pretty empty.  We ordered the veggie dumplings, veggie noodle soup, onion pancakes, and xiao long bao.  They ran out of veggie potstickers ):

Everything was more or less alright.  The hand pulled noodles were very chewy, and the soup was light.  The pancakes were a bit oily.

Service was like your average Chinese restaurant, almost nonexistent.  We had a slight mishap with the bill at the end.  Street parking shouldn't be too hard to find.  Look along 21st.
author: Katherine C.

description: The hand pulled noodles were really long and tasted slightly chewy, so it was perfect for my taste. Seems the noodles were all hand made in the kitchen, according to the photos in the windows.  Mayor Lee also came here, as shown in the photo on the wall.  Dumplings were good.  Use the vinegar they provide on the table as dipping sauce for the the dumplings to bring out the taste.  String beans came piping hot and were delicious.  Would go back to try the big signature dish, literally translated from Chinese is 'big bowl chicken' that I noticed everyone was eating when we left. Staff were super friendly.  A nice little place for comfort food.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Worst place ever. They change another chief who cooked like shit, and also rude service. One of my favorite places in SF before, but not gonna come next time.
author: Chao D.

description: Delicious and authentic Chinese food. For noodles so far we have tried Xinjiang Noodle and Special Hot Oil Noodle. They are both delicious!! If you like Chinese pancake, order the Beef Pancake. it is one the best beef pancake I have had. We also tried the Chives Pancake. Crispy on the outside with delicious chives and egg filling. You won't be disappointed with the food here.
author: Shinta L.

description:
This worst review is about their customer service.
The 1 star (negative if possible) review is not for their food. I even couldn't get there.

On Sunday, about lunch time, we put our name on the waiting list (marker and white board. Typical method at popular Chinese restaurant around the area) . 
We waited good 40 min. I knew finally it's our turn for the next call.

A lady from the restaurant came outside, she showed 2 fingers which I guessed "2 people".
I approached her, told her that it would be us.  She just ignored me and talked another couple whom came after us in Chinese, then let them bring inside for seating.  I guess she doesn't speak any English, which is still OK, but she even didn't bothered to bring the white board to see or just simply try to communicate to us.

I was very upset especially after long waiting in hot sunny sidewalk. 
They have English menu, but WTF, don't show the menu in English if you don't care other than Chinese.
author: Manatee T.

description:
Great place for hand pulled noodles! It really hits the spot when cravings for home-cooking creeps up. I can't say that this place is mind blowing but it meets all my criteria for "mom's comfort food." 

I had the fennel dumplings, pan-fried bread (生煎包), and beef noodle soup (牛腩麵). 

Fennel dumplings: it was a great take for a toned down version of the traditional chive dumpling (韭菜水餃). The fennel flavor was subtle enough where I didn't feel like I was eating a savory licorice dumpling but strong enough to complement the chives. The dumplings however were a little overcooked. 

Pan-fried bread: not the best take on this dish but it wasn't bad. I would say it's just about average. Contrary to the dumplings, this dish could have been pan fried a bit longer to achieve that delicious crispy bottom. The filling was pretty good and didn't give me an oily mouth-feel. 

Beef noodle soup: the specialty of this place are their hand-pulled noodles (手拉麵) as to which I must agree. Their noodles were perfectly cooked and still tasted great when I ate my leftovers the next day. This was the definition of homey comfort food. The flavors weren't mind-blowing and 5-star status but eating it reminded me of the flavors I grew up with. I would totally order this dish again when I'm missing home.
author: Victoria C.

description:
The place to go for dumplings if you're around the Taraval area.  And for during cold weather, a good place for their spicy dishes.  The spicy beef noodle soup definitely warmed me up.  Prices are cheap, very affordable.

The food is good, and the people working here knows it.  Which is why they don't bother on service.  They don't try to welcome you here, unless you're a regular and can go on a full length conversation with them in Mandarin.
author: Karen L.

description:
Quaint. Authentic. Delicious. 

Tiny, packed little restaurant seats 20 people max. The atmosphere is homey and feels like the hustle and bustle of grandma's at Christmas. 

Dumplings are superb. Flavor is perfect and sauce is delectable - only drawback is the slightly thick dough. 

They're known for their hand drawn noodles - you must order one of them. The noodles are firm and not soggy, they are cooked perfectly and the sauce with almost any dish is rich and delicious. 

The price is reasonable for fresh made pasta, albeit a little high.
author: Kyle C.

description:
This was my second visit to this restaurant, (once again due to Smile House Cafe having a long wait) and I don't think I will ever be returning. 

Food: 2/5
-Dumplings: Lukewarm, thick skin, and salty. I'm normally a person who enjoys my food more flavorful and salty compared to it being bland. However, the meat was overwhelmingly salty and felt as if it was indulged in soy sauce. 
-Dry Cooked Chicken Wings: Disappointing. I guess it was my fault to blame that I imagined this dish to be similar to San Tung chicken wings. Well, at least having somewhat of a familiar taste. However, the chicken wings were just fried with little pieces of bell peppers and onions - basically just tasted like it was cooked with salt and pepper. 

I have tried their noodles before and I must say, those are the better dishes offered from this restaurant. 

Service:  
Two chefs, two waiters, ten tables of customers, what do you expect? Upon my visit, three tables complained of the long wait for their dishes and the chaos of the order in which food was served. Two tables down, I hear a table of four complaining that they had been waiting for more than 30 minutes, yet no food had been served. Meanwhile, a table that had arrived later than them had their dishes delivered already. No apologies mentioned, nothing but shy aways. To my right, a table canceled their order for dumplings due to the long wait while the table to my left complained about a missing plate of dumplings. And here I was, finding myself wanting to find the whereabouts of my food as I watched a table that arrived later than mine have their food delivered.
author: Eva C.

description: As I was driving around looking for some authentic Chinese food in Taraval I saw this restaurant, I stand and check out the menu by the door and the only thing convince me is the pictures outside, it looks so good. I ask the waitress what is the best handmade noodle is here and she replied try E1 XianJong noodle and I saw someone order the pork dumplings too and the beef pancake. I said to the waitress I want to order those 3 dishes, she smile at me and said sure . I finish the XianJong lamb noodle and try to finish the dumplings and the pancake. I will come again and tell my friends about this place.
author: Hendrik N.

description:
The best Da Pan Ji I have ever had in this area! Basically Da Pan Ji is stewed chicken with thick chewy noodles on the bottom. The chicken should be very flavorful and the noodles should absorb all the good flavors from the meat and the Chinese spices including Chinese peppercorns and star anise.

Also, get the dumplings too, the skins of the dumplings are thin, and the stuffing is fulfilling.

Service is not the most friendly service, but they do get the job done.

Tip: order Da Pan Ji ahead, it usually takes more than 20 minutes to come out.
author: Emma Y.

description:
Food was okay. I would only come here if I had a craving to come here.

We ordered the egg wrapped onion pancake, fish dumplings, shrimp/chive dumplings and the 3 seafood noodle soup.

The Egg Wrapped Onion Pancake was okay. For something so seemingly hefty, and yummy looking, it didn't pack as much of a flavor as I was hoping.

The dumplings were okay. They came in a heaping amount of a dozen per plate. I advise not to order the fish dumplings, but the shrimp and chive dumplings were okay. 

The 3 Seafood Noodle Soup had tasty hand pulled noodles in my opinion, but everything else in the soup was mediocre. I would say there were 5-6 servings in the bowl.

I came here one time before and if my memory recalls, the vegetable pot stickers were pretty good, so i'll have to come back to refresh my memory. But again, this place is okay; i'm not in love with any of the food, but it's not bad enough to scare me away. (Service is mediocre so don't expect princess service)
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I can see why this place has only 3 stars..

Located right on Taraval, this place has some good competition and honestly, I don't think it's gonna win. 

Parking is all on the streets and metered till 6pm unless you want to try parking in the residential area.

The inside of this place is tiny. Like, wow. One step inside and you can see majority of the place. The tables are close together and makes it a bit hard to maneuver out of if it's crowded. I will say this- their seats are comfortable. 

Service is bad. I don't know if all the workers speak mandarin, but the one we got did and while my mom's good at speaking it, the girl was still a bit slow to understand. Which isn't a problem, but she just stood there looking at us at first and it was awkward. And through the rest of dinner, I noticed that not one single server actually attempted to smile or be nice. They were like robots writing down orders, cleaning tables, and bring food out. That's it. Think of those workers at Quickly's, but in a restaurant setting instead. 

Food is eh. Their pig ears are good in my opinion and so are their dumplings, but that beef wrap and green onion pancake were bad. The pancakes were too oily and the beef wrap lack sauce to improve the taste. All I could really remember from either dishes was the oil that was leftover on my fingers and mouth. 

Overall, probably not gonna come back. There are better dumpling places on Taraval, guys!
author: Venus L.

description: I've been to this restaurant once previously and the service was not terrible. When I went again on 8/20/17, my mom and I had a really bad experience. We (along with one other family) got seated around 11:12 a.m. (before they were officially open) and we placed our order relatively quickly. The other family proceeds to get their food before us. Another couple walks in about 10 min after us and orders. They also get their food before us. We asked the waiter why that was the case. He told us he didn't know because we should have gotten our food first. We continued to wait a few more minutes before we were told that the cook would start on our food next (this at 11:40 a.m.). We ended up walking out without our food. Would NOT recommend coming here--we definitely won't!
author: Victoria W.

description:
Got the beef pancake and also the "Comb soup" at the suggestion of our waitress. I'm pretty sure it was supposed to say combo, but I don't want to mislead anyone if its not.

the soup did not disappoint. It was slightly spicy and filled with all sorts of meats I don't care to identify. The spice was the perfect touch and made this soup especially good. I think I'd come back here just for some more of the soup.

The pancake was alright. Typical chinese pancake though slightly greasy because of the beef. The beef was also proportioned funny as 2 pieces were like all meat. One piece had 0 meat and the 4th piece was like 25% meat. It made for some awkward pancake bites.
author: Courtney Q.

description:
Had my favorite mutton with bread crumb noodle soup. I liked it, plenty of meat and hearty soup. Sat in the back next to register at a two person table.

Owner decides to sit at my table, play with his phone, and have a casual chat with his coworkers. Hey man, I love your food but can you give a guy some space to enjoy it? I mean, do I need to be Xi Jinping to get some quiet time to enjoy my noodle?
author: Chris H.

description:
A pretty ok restaurant.  Solid 3-stars. 

Pros: 
Big portions.  We ordered the chicken/corn dumplings and the pork/chive dumplings, and there were 12 of each.  We came for the noodles, but the dumplings were the highlight. 
Good flavor.  I can't say anything bad about the taste of the food.  We ordered dumplings, black bean noodles, and the xinjiang noodles.  I was expecting the noodles to be like a soup dish, but they were actually thick pasta-like dishes.  Everything tasted good, and seemed well prepared.  I would recommend any of those dishes. 
They also got all our order correct, I had asked for bell peppers to be left off the noodles and they made sure that none were added.
The tea with the meal was yummy too.

Cons:
Slow.  Service definitely leaves a bit to be desired.  Don't expect the staff to be overly friendly, though this may be attributed to a language barrier.  
Kinda dirty.  The walls were seriously gross, but our plates/cutlery appeared to be clean. 
Parking... It's San Francisco, what do you expect.
author: Jen G.

description: Fam and I wanted to go eat dumplings and noodles on Christmas morning, but our usual places were all closed.  Thank God we stumbled on this gem!!  They make their noodles and dumpling skins in house here, and boy do they make them well.  The wheat noodles are nice and chewy here - really, really pleasant to eat.  The dumpling skins are nice and chewy as well, and the filling is very nicely done - good seasoning AND the fat renders into broth super nicely in the lamb and sea cucumber dumplings.  The Xian noodles were good too, like rough-cut/rustic ho fun noodles.  Overall, I am a big fan. The place is small though, so there could be a wait.
author: Tracey L.

description:
This place was perfect for what I was craving. Picked it randomly because it was the only thing open at 3:45pm and first time in the area. 
I asked for a popular dish and they recommended the cold noodles. Well please with the Cold noodles and tea. The Noodles have a lot of flavor and are fresh real noodles. Good Garlick aftertaste! Check this place out!!
author: Michael H.

description: A hole in the wall restaurant but they serve authentic northern Chinese food.  I love the beef pan cake, and the dumplings. The noodle is freshly made on the spot and you can see him pulling the noodles.  The texture of the noodle is perfect.  You just have to get use to the hole in the wall environment.
author: Kit L.

description:
Shandong Noodles has become one of our favorite neighborhood eating spots, it's a rather modest looking place on the outside, when one wonders in, it's not always clear of how your seats are will be assigned, but when the menu comes out and you start ordering, the food just delights beyond your expectations.

We rather like the pan fried dumplings, which delight with their steamy beef nuggets inside, and the cucumber salad adds a cool taste to the meal, but best of all, so far, are the Xian cold noodles with their peanut sauce. 

From how each dish has been pleasurable, I'm excited to go back and try some more of the menu
author: Paul M.

description: The xianjian noodles are amazing!! Let alone, i will give that a 5/5. The noodles taste fresh and are bouncy! There are two variations.. the cheap one and the expensive one which is over $20. Ive never had the expensive one but hopefully someday will. Knowing the cheaper one is just as amazing should be enough anyway! The orange spicy sauce is so amazing and hot!! It goes well with just about anything. I love the pan fried dumplings here too. I would skip on the steamed dumplings, there are other locations on taraval that specialize in that.
author: Tina O.

description: Hands down the best handmade dumplings and noodles I've had so far. These are even better than the ones I had in China
author: Ron A.

description: Terrible. One of our items was the wrong one, the noodle soup didn't come with small bowls, scissors, or even a spoon, and the dumplings come on sets of 12 instead of 20 like the menu says. Outright deception! Staff doesn't come around too much. Avoid like the plague.
author: David L.

description:
Didn't come here for a while. I ordered the following:

-Pig Ears (Good but the portion were smaller than before)
-Beef Stew Noodle Soup (Just OK / No taste & only 3 small pieces of beef)

I don't think I will come back anymore!

*Service were just OK
author: Wendy L.

description:
If you like supporting small businesses, Shandong Deluxe is right up your alley.  Not only are they family owned/operated (I think the father and son work the kitchen while the mom and daughter work the tables), but their size certainly qualifies as "small"!  House of Pancakes up the street may be smaller, but seating here is just as tight and limited.  Just ask the people who had to slide in out of their seats so that the people at the neighboring table could get out...

With a menu that leans towards Northern Chinese cuisine, the vast majority of Shandong Deluxe's dishes revolve around dumplings and noodles.  However, they do offer a few staples from other Chinese cuisines (like Xiao Long Baos).  Still, my family and I were more interested in trying their specialties:

-- SALT & PEPPER FRIED TOFU...$5.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco#o7IfCb2v24QebqmazCE6wQ)
The portion was a pleasant surprise, and I liked the crisp batter, but the dish was underseasoned.  Not that I would want a ton of salt/MSG, but the tofu was really bland, which was only exacerbated by the fact that there were so many pieces.

-- SHEN JIAN BAO - Pan Fried Pork Dumplings...$4.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco#HrDs0ocIp3boMbZf4TKHVw)
Although it's a Shanghainese dish, I had to try it.  The skin had a nice thickness and there was a good amount of filling, but the meat just wasn't that flavorful. It's still not bad overall, but it doesn't come close to my favorite down the street (Dumpling Kitchen).

-- PORK DUMPLINGS WITH NAPA CABBAGE...$5.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco#MGLI_kwAUQflWl9qYQifNg)
See above.  While the dumplings were just as plump, the filling also fell short.  I don't know if there was too much cabbage or lean meat, but the pork just wasn't that juicy.  Still, it's not like they were bad (I liked them better than the Shen Jian Baos).

-- BEEF STEW NOODLE SOUP...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco#fQGzbeZXJohvGwgr5rjxGw)
Probably the highlight of the night.  The beef was mostly tender and I thought the noodles terrific (the consistency was perfect).  Even though the broth could have been "beefier", I liked how it was slightly peppery.

Although none of our dishes may have overwhelmed us, I can't say we had any complaints about the experience either.  The wait wasn't bad, service was nice, and prices were quite friendly.  There may be better restaurants in the area, but Shandong Deluxe deserves some praise for putting out decent food at great prices.  For that reason alone, I'd come back.

CASH ONLY.
author: Mike L.

description:
bean curd shred was good
dumplings were ok
la pi was good
author: Diane W.

description:
Finally came here for dinner since it opened even I live just two blocks away. The reason is because I've been a fan of House of Pancakes that is across the street, the line here is always hella long, and the fiancé had a bad experience here. Therefore, it wasn't really on my list to try. But we were hungry and there was no wait, so why not try!

Maybe because my expectations were already lowered hearing my fiance's experience, but I was pleasantly surprised by their pork/Napa cabbage dumpling. Compared to the pork/Napa cabbage dumplings at HOP, I think I actually like these more. We also tried their spicy beef noodle, it was overall okay- noodles were good, but the soup, beef, veg was just okay. Also tried their bean curd since I'm just a fan of bean curd, and it was average. 

Cash only. I have yet to eat something here that is impressive. And I would not wait an hr to eat here.
author: Iris H.

description: The noodles is very good, make fresh on site. but the broth and flavors needs improvement, no deep! Too plain!  just salt and pepper, don't know how to use seasoning.
author: Michael D.

description: The place to go for dumplings in the Sunset. I came in late in the afternoon for lunch and the restaurant was still packed even though it wasn't lunch time. I got the Pork Dumplings and the Zhajiangmein aka Black Bean Noodles. The Pork Dumplings were freshly made and had a lot of meat. The Zhajiangmein had noodles that were handmade in their own kitchen, there was also the right amount of sauce for the portion of noodles. They should add more chicken though for the noodles though. The service here is fair, there was only one waiter taking orders and serving the restaurant. Would return later to try the other types of dumplings they have to offer.
author: Peter C.

description:
Food here is pretty good, especially their noodle dishes. I usually get their lamb noodle soup, just basic lamb chunks with hand pulled noodles, a few mushrooms, served in clear broth. It's nothing too fancy but somehow it's hits the spot. Dumplings are alright, not amazing or anything. They have some interesting dumplings like the sea cucumber dumpling. Curious but nah. They have this dish called Xinjiang Style Chicken with Noodle that is worth trying. It's a spicy dish, so avoid if you're not a chili fan. There's pieces of potato, chili, chicken (with bones) served over a bed of thick, measuring tape looking noodle. Imagine chow fun type fo noodle but extra chewy and thick, that's the noodle's texture. This dish takes time to prepare, some people call in, or just order it first thing when you sit down. It's definitely a family size dish, you can probably split it with 4-6 people.

Other than the food, this place has the best service ever! No one to greet you, no one to look over at your table when you're like raising your hand for their attention, slow to take your orders, doesn't bus tables quick enough even if there's a long line of people waiting to be seated, has a credit card sticker at the door but won't let you use credit card to pay because they are closing in an hour. Everything you can name for bad service, they've done it. Typical Chinese place, but worse? Probably.  If you can brush off all of those stuff, then yes, definitely give it a go.
author: Connie C.

description:
I can't believe it's only three stars on Yelp. The only explanation is probably you can't rely on Yelp review to tell you the true story of authentic ethnic food. 

Delicious. Delicious. Delicious.
author: Shuang J.

description:
Having been born and bred in Beijing, I'm a slight snob when it comes to Northern Chinese cuisine. Shandong Deluxe has the core makings of a good Northern Chinese restaurant, but I think the execution fell a little short of expectation. 

The restaurant itself is a small, hole-in-the-wall place, with crowded tables and a small corridor in the back that has both tables and kitchen staff making the food. Service is friendly and efficient enough, although being able to speak Chinese does make things easier.

Cold flat noodles with sliced cucumber and sesame sauce:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco?select=MMi8D5prN9FI1lLQyJMstQ#CLgjGww5rHW9BEN4g6zhkg)
The sesame sauce on this dish was amaaaazing, definitely reminiscent of the kind I used to have in the street vendor noodle dishes back in China. The flat noodles were initially of good texture, and you could tell that they were hand-made, but unfortunately they were a little over-boiled, which caused them to be a bit waterlogged and softer than optimal. I liked the contrast of the crunchy cucumber and soft noodles, but there was some watery sauce on the bottom that was a little unappetizing towards the end when the last bits of noodle were swimming around in there. Good flavor, but I think the execution could use a bit of work.

Dan Dan Mian with hand-pulled noodles:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco?select=MMi8D5prN9FI1lLQyJMstQ#Lr8rLySle8GICq5agDaxvA)
I haven't had Dan Dan Mian at many places since I don't usually eat spicy foods, but the broth on this had good flavor. It was pretty salty though, and the spiciness was a little reminiscent of the sauce that was in the condiment section of each table. I tried some of the actual hand-pulled noodles though, and those were really good. You can really tell that they were hand-pulled, as the elasticity was on point. 

Pork and chive dumplings:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco?select=MMi8D5prN9FI1lLQyJMstQ#nWJIZ6YVJ2AUsFAERMczGw)
These dumplings were a little disappointing. They had the "hand squeezed" look of authentic Northern dumplings, but they were way overboiled and super waterlogged. I was not a fan of the execution on these at all, and they would have been really good if they had not been so overboiled. The pork and chive mixture inside was tasty, but a little bit salty, and there was that juiciness that was reminiscent of soup buns. They sell frozen dumplings as well, so I might opt to just buy the frozen version next time and go home to boil them myself.

I might drop by again if I'm in the area to try some of their other noodles (beef tendon sounded good!), but I'm a little wary of the execution of the cook here. Also, I'm not sure if they over-salt their dishes or use MSG, as my friend and I both had slight headaches after eating here.
author: Maggie X.

description: This is a great restaurant on the busy Taraval street. Although the service isn't always as quick, the food is always consistent. In fact, the hand cranked noodles and frozen dumplings are a treat. The price for the food is really reasonable.
author: Justin C.

description: Go there for the food, not for the service; especially during peak hours. Love the dumplings- heavy filling in chives, great favor, but not proportional to the protein. Noodles are fantastic; handed made and great texture. The soup, not many variety. There are only 2 kinds: spicy or clear broth, but worth trying. Pot stickers, not the best, but huge serving size. Overall , love their food 4/5. Service: 1/5
author: Simon L.

description:
A hot bowl of spicy pork and seafood noodle soup.   Hand pulled noodle.   So perfect.  I'm now warm and toasty.  Attacked my bowl so fast I didn't even think to get a picture.    I've been to their sister restaurant on Geary and second.   I usually love their cold xian noodle appetizer but needed something warmer today.

Their dumplings are good esp if you like lamb.  Their potstickers are good and we always get the hot sweet soy milk.  

I really like their noodle soup.  Noodles are perfectly cooked with a little chew.  

Plus nice waiter didn't mind me charting until my next appointment.
author: Regi K.

description:
Shandong is a frequent of mine for their some of their cheap and simple dishes.

My favorites and the must trys of Shandong are:
*Bean curd Noodle Salad - My reason for coming here.  The dish is served cold and contains bean curd noodles tossed with salt and I think sesame oil.
*Dumplings - There are about 10-15 types of dumplings on the menu.  My favorite is the pork, shrimp, and chive dumplings.  The dumplings are boiled and comes in orders of 12.
*Lamb skewers - Delicious!  The lamb is sprinkled with many spices and the lamb didn't have a gamey taste.
*Hot & Sour Soup - They don't skimp on the contents.  It contains plenty of pieces of tofu, bamboo shoots, chopped woodear mushrooms, and carrot slivers.  Do beware, it's really spicy.  Most of the time I tap out at a bowl and a half.

I'm not a fan of their Shanghai soup dumplings/Xiao Long Bao (6 pieces) because most of the time they're a fail.  The skin is too thick but most of them seem to crack before they hit your table and the soup has already leaked out.  Aside from that, the pork filling is delicious.

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Cash only. Banks located nearby
*Make use of the hot sauce on the table.  It has a good kick to it.
*Noodles are made in house
*If you go during peak times, expect a wait
*Service is a hit or miss.  Sometimes it's attentive, most of the time you're stuck waving someone down
*Open daily
*Metered street parking which can often be difficult to find
author: Nicole S.

description:
I prefer cup of noodles over the noodles here. 
I only ordered the noodles so I don't how the other dishes are. Other people on our table ordered the chow mein they said, it sucks and did't finish it. The waiter and waitress are sometimes deaf, because you have to yell for service.
author: S C.

description:
Food is less than expected!  But service is absolutely terrible!

I had lunch there on a weekday.  I ordered two noodle dishes and had finished eating around 1:30 pm.  Requested the check, paid, and while waiting for the change back, one of us went to use the rest room.  As he is still at the bathroom, a group of 11 people came in and was looking for a table; the owner/waiter (his picture was on the wall, so I assume he is one of the owners) quickly clean the table when I was still sitting sipping tea waiting for him.  The owner/waiter picked up the change and try to pocket them but felt he shouldn't at the same time.  He struggled back and fourth 3 times taking the tips, then put the change back onto the table.  In the mean time, several of the people from the group of 11 begins to sit down at our table impolitely!  So the owner/waiter said, "please take the change back, no need to give us tips!"  From my perspective, this is what restaurants should never do, chase your customer out!  I really think what he meant in action is, "never come back and tell everyone not to come either!"
author: Benedict L.

description:
