I wish I could give it a non-star. This place is suck. I was born and grew up in Shandong, China, and I know how Shandong food tastes and looks. I should not expect that Shandong food here tastes the same as Shandong food back in China, but food here is no where close to Shandong food. There are not many dishes are Shandong food on menu. 

1. Pork Dumplings
The skin is so thick and the filling is so small. Shandong Pork Dumplings should have thin skin and big filling. The Napa Cabbage is not fresh because it is squashy. You name your dish pork dumpling. Are you kidding me?

2. Black Bean W Pork Noddle (Zha Jiang Mian)
 Zha Jiang Mian is a disappointment. It is freaking salty, and I can't find much pork. In addition, it has big pieces of Chinese Onion pieces. I like Chinese Onion, but why the heck it comes in big pieces? It should be in small pieces so that the sauce can have much more onion flavor.  Further more, it should come with small and thin cucumber slices. Where is it?

3. Five Spice Fish (Xun Yu)
Are you kidding me? The fish pieces are very hard. It means that it is not fresh at all. It was probably cooked and frozen a few days ago. Five Spice Fish tastes good only if you eat it right after you cook it. This is not authentic at all.

4. Xinjiang Doddle W Lamb
This is not a Shandong dish. I don't know how it should taste. However, I can't find much lamb but just lots of noodle. 

I don't want to comment anymore. Nothing is authentic. I came with excitement but left with huge disappointment. I will NEVER come back again, and I do NOT recommend it to anybody. It is not expensive, but it is not worth the money. 

If you want to have some authentic Shandong food. I recommend you Taste of Shandong (Its Black Bean W Pork Noddle comes with small and thin cucumber slices and small Chinese Onion pieces. Absolutely authentic!!!) on Judah St and 9th Ave. It is proven Shangdong taste and it is not expensive, either.
author: Yukai K.

description: This place serves authentic chinese food for a great price. Their portions are rather big so plan to go with a big group. Some dishes i would recommend would be to order the hand tossed noodles(8-9$) or the spicy chicken pot (28$).
author: Ricky C.

description:
Great noodles, but you can skip the buns and onion pancake. Feels dirty and some food came surprisingly slow... but if you like the noodles at terracotta warrior, these are almost as good!

The black bean noodles were great! While I've tasted better black bean sauce, the hand-pulled noodles were chewy and had amazing texture. For less than $10, it was a pretty good portion.

The lamb noodles were similarly great. The lamb was soft and flavorful while the noodles were perfect. The soup was a clear broth so the lamb flavor was really clear and strong. Also under $10, good portion. 

The onion pancake (~$6) came really late, after everything else. It lacked flavor and was flimsy, not crispy or crunchy at all. 

The pork dumpling with chives (~$6) was not bad and definitely was flavorful. The meat was also nice and juicy, but the noodles were just better.

I highly recommend the noodles!! If you can overlook the decor and inconsistent service, this is a solid place to grab authentic hand-pulled noodles. You can skip everything else on the menu though.
author: Grace C.

description:
Despite the mixed reviews, this place is still pretty popular and you're definitely getting what you're paying for; yummy authentic food + less than average service. But I'm still a fan!

Tip: Cash only!! 

Pros:
-authentic, fresh, homemade, flavorful dumpling filling with THICK hand-made dumpling skin. My family does not make dumplings on our own from scratch so I've learned over the years to appreciate the quality of thick, chewy handmade dumpling skins!!! This place is definitely where it's at.
-not too salty, but just right. In my opinion, Shandong has the proportions right for  taste+filling vs. thickness of dumpling skin. YUM!!
-fresh. Everything you order is hot right off the stove. Gotta love hot foods :) 
-fast. Ok let me clarify - while the service isn't the best (don't expect it to be, it's a hole in the wall restaurant), once you do manage to get your order in, it's in. And they're cooking it! Our 3 orders came out quickly together after we ordered.
-cheap! We ordered 3 dishes for 2 people (ate til we were full) and paid $24 total including tax and tip! 
-the orange homemade hot sauce. It's hot and it's good. Mix it with the soy sauce. Enough said.
-conveniently located on Taraval near the muni line. Can take the L-line there and walk over within 3 mins. 

Cons:
-if you read the other low star reviews, it's mostly attributed to service. But like I said, don't expect to be treated like you're royalty. They're busy cooking everything from scratch! Be supportive and take initiative to help yourself :P
-even if there is a wait list, wait inside or check back often to see if there is movement. If the restaurant isn't packed, they're not going to look at the wait list. My friend and I were sitting on the chairs outside and were wondering what was taking so long. We went inside and realized no one was checking the wait list and there were a few empty tables. They gave us a table and hot tea right away after that.
-...but no menu. They have a box of blue paper menus near the entrance. Or table was close enough for me to notice that so I went up and got one.
-we had to call our waiter over to order. Seems like this place is short staffed. (However after we got our order in the food came out pretty fast afterwards!)
-had to ask for refills on the hot tea

Le Menu:
-chicken and corn dumplings. My friend visits this place often and highly recommended this one. Especially if you love corn!
-pork and leek dumplings. Also a good one
-leek pancake. YOU MUST GET THIS. Super hot and crisp, delicious, and satisfying.

We were both super full and I even got to take 6 or 7 dumplings home to bring for lunch the next day = win :) (and btw, they were still amazing the next day). I shall be back again soon!
author: Grace J.

description:
This little restaurant is great! It offers authentic Chinese food from Northern China. Their hand made noodles are the best I ever had in the US. The handmade noodles made here are exactly like the noodles I had in Urumchi, Xinjiang when I traveled there. Stir fried lamb with noodles is my most favorite dishes.

They also provide dumplings, steam buns, Chinese pancakes etc. All those are handmade.
author: Cool G.

description:
The food is good but the service and wait time is bad. That's probably why 3 star on yelp review.

Everything here is pretty good. Love their handmade noodles and dumplings here. Give this place a shot before skipping them.
author: Steven C.

description:
I can't believe this place only has 3 stars!! Here's my story. My friend brought me here once and I ended up coming back 2 more times after that over the span of 2 weeks. I NEVER DO THAT!! Plus, I was on spring break from the east coast, so these meal choices were precious. 3 times in 3 weeks. That alone should tell you how good this place is. 

I've been incredibly happy with almost everything I've gotten here. My favorites include:
- BEEF ROLLS: the best I've ever had. Great ratio of fresh veggies!
- DUMPLINGS: the skin is better at San Tung, but the filling is better here!! The skin is too thick, but its okay because the filling is SOO juicy and flavorful. 
- CHIVE PANCAKES: delicious chives stuffed in a wonderfully crisp pancake. 
- FUNGUS, EGG, AND FLOWER NOODLE: the noodles here a great! And the broth was not too salty like it usually is at other Chinese restaurants. 
- BLACK BEAN NOODLES/ja jang mien: because hand pulled noodles!!

The only dish I wasn't a huge fan of was the Dan Dan Noodles...which tasted like a mix of peanut butter and chili to me. This might just be a personal preference though. 

I've noticed most of the negative reviews are mainly about the service. But damn, when prices are that cheap and the food is that authentic, I've learned to expect that! The $ you save is compensated in the lack of service. That's just how it works at cheap Chinese restaurants. 

The main con for me is the rate that they bring out your dishes. Every time I've gone, they've been quick to bring out most of your dishes, but there has ALWAYS been one dish that arrives after you finish eating everything else! 

PS make a trip to the bathroom, where you can see workers making the dumplings out in the open!
author: Carolyn L.

description:
I hate to write a 4 star review for my shan dong people, but the service here was lacking.  I came at 11am on a weekday, the place wasn't packed, but for whatever reason it took them 35 minutes for a bowl of noodles and dumplings... was highly disappointed (they also messed up my noodle order and brought me another tables noodles).  However, the food was all on point, tasted like home cooking that I grew up with.

I got the noodles with mushrooms - taste was pretty authentic, definitely like my moms cooking! The noodle broth had a very deep and rich flavor, with hints of cinnamon, cloves, and star anise - just how they do it in Shan Dong.  This is northern cuisine, which is notorious for having heavy flavored foods and really big people! 

Dumplings were well worth it, one serving is about 12 dumplings, and they are SUPER legit and cheap.  You can easily tell that the skins were made in house.  Honestly I don't know why chinese food has to be so cheap, when it's just as laborious as making fresh pasta.
author: Timothy S.

description:
This is a pretty cozy neighborhood place. You can tell it's super Chinese because decor is an afterthought, and they didn't bother to remove the Japanese paintings from the previous restaurant that was here. There's nothing wrong with that. I just think it's funny. 

Anyway, I wasn't able to try the dumplings, but we had the Lamb Skewers, Spicy Beef Noodle Soup, and Lamb Noodle Soup.

The Lamb Skewers had a good amount of meat on them, but they were pretty tough and kind of bland. Although it looked like they were seasoned thoroughly, they weren't that flavorful. I thought they didn't have enough cumin to bring out the lamb's flavor. A little salt could've helped too.

In both noodle soups, the noodles were the highlight and had a delightful toothsome chewiness. The soups could have been better though. The Spicy Beef Soup didn't have a strong foundation. It was spicy and a little sour, but there was no beefiness in the broth. It kind of just tasted like hot sauce and water. The Lamb Noodle Soup was a little bit better, but the broth still wasn't very robust. There was a shiitake earthiness and slight gamey flavor in the broth, but it was still leaning heavily on the bland side. In general, it doesn't seem like their broths are very well developed. Like San Tung on Irving, maybe the thick saucy type of noodles are better. I'll have to try those next time.
author: Nei N.

description:
Family own and run?  check.
Small hole-in-wall type place?  check.
Authentic cuisine?  check.... well, at least, judging by the mostly Mandarin speaking dining customers it seems so.
Quick service?  check.
Satisfied customers?  check.

Being on Taraval Monday afternoon, we cruised by several restaurants between 19th and 21st Avenue, examining menus as we walked.  We chose this restaurant since it had a) the most interesting menu and b) the most dining customers.  The restaurant name posted on its front signage prominently describes their signature specialty:  hand pulled noodles (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) (okay, they describe it as "hand cranked"?).  Here's what we ordered:

Appetizers (shared)
1) Handwritten appetizer #A - My English description is Yuba strips and marinated vegetables with peanuts (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=7T256d1661SEA9KHsEFO-w&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Reminds me of Hodoy Soy's Yuba strips, but a bit more watery from the cucumber.

2) Bean Curd Noodle Salad - Tasty but pretty one dimensional.

3) Shandong Style Marinated Chicken (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=GXIwks6wo5RA0RFazqDYPA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Reminds me of drunken chicken without the alcohol.  The timing on the marinating is good as the flavor and texture (soft and not dry) were spot on.

Entree
4) Beef Stew Noodle (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=XG9J6HxZ1jhAeO6za33R7w&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Hand pulled noodles (unmistakable with the varying width of the noodle strands) are not my favorite as they tend to be more doughy than ramen al dente crunchy.  Soup was okay with five-spice ingredients, mainly star anise and peppercorns (careful when biting those black balls on the bottom).

Vegetables (shared)
5) Sautee (sp) Bok Choy (Ching Gong Chai) -  The English wording doesn't quite match the veggies served here.  Need to refer to Ken K. for a more accurate translation, but they cooked this well with diced garlic.

While walking to the restroom, I noticed a lady kneading and folding chive turnovers (Jiu chai he zhi).  The older gentleman in the posted photo (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shandong-deluxe-san-francisco?select=3z3b7zYuf185YImVHchAtA#3z3b7zYuf185YImVHchAtA) walked the dining room, serving food and checking on dining customers.  At the front window, it clearly displays the man pulling noodles (noodle master) and the lady doing what she was doing (dumpling duchess).  Watching other diners order a variety of food, I will be back to try them and discover what their signature dishes are.
author: Mike C.

description:
I checked out this place with a friend who is local to the area. With the high concentration of Chinese restaurants in the area, it was nice to be able to pick one out that came highly recommended.

We came here for dinner on a Monday night at 6:30pm and got a table for 3 right away. Seating is somewhat limited and the restaurant got busier around 7:30pm with a short wait so come early. 

We ordered 3 dishes for 3 people which wound up being the perfect amount of food. The dishes were as follows:
1. Pork Dumpling with Chives - The dumpling skin had a good texture. It wasn't too thick and had a good chew to it. The pork was well seasoned and had a great consistency. Sometimes I find that dumpling places can be a little sloppy with the meat and there's often unsavory bits that are inedible but there was none of that today. The chives are a classic complement are were a nice flavor bump. Definitely above average. 
2. Onion Pancake - Great item. The plate came with 8 good sized pieces. They were crispy, a nice thickness and extremely flavorful. The only thing I would say is that they were a bit oily.
3. Xinjian Noodle - This was one of their signature dishes and it fell a little flat for me. I'm not entirely sure what this dish is made up of traditionally but we opted for the beef version. Aside from noodles and beef, there were veggies including red and green peppers, white button mushrooms and onions. The noodles themselves were pretty good. I am told they are hand pulled and made in the restaurant. The overall flavor of the dish was okay. Nothing too crazy but good. The veggies were kinda meh and there was a lot of water seepage from it all. 

All in all this place is decent. I don't think I'd run back the exact same dishes but I'd want to try what else the restaurant has to offer.
author: Emily L.

description:
I don't know why this place has such a low rating. TBH, this place is a great place to go for noodles, esp "LA MEIN".

I used to get dumplings and noodles (dan dan mein) at "dumpling kitchen". Since they don't open on Wednesday, bf and I passed by this place at 11:30, right after they opened, and decided to give it a try. The first time here, we are IN LOVED with their noodles.

First-time visit, I got the spicy pork noodle (less spicy cuz idk how spicy it would be for "shandong people"). The bowl of noodles came out pretty fast. The bowl of soup is orange/red-ish? OH! It must be hot sauce i guess? I tried the soup with a spoon hoping its not THAT spicy, but guess what, it tastes so good, a little hint of spicy taste last on my tongue, its not like super duper spicy. (Cuz i got some crazy hot sauce from other "shandong" place before). The texture of the noodles: chewy and elastic, pretty awesome noodles here. I guess they make it themselves? cuz I haven't tried any of the machine-made-noodles has this kind of texture. It's really really good. WOULD RECOMMEND TO FRIENDS.

We also got the pork dumpling with spinach. It has a huge chopped spinach with pork inside the dumpling. It tastes nothing really special, just spinach with pork with the outside part (flours/men fun? LOL) but we like it too. FYI: dine in or take out -12 pieces. Take out with "raw/uncook dumpling" - 20 pieces. Don't let the menu fool you LOL.

We also got the beef fried rice noodle (beef chow ho fun). Not much beef, but a big portion of rice noodles. The rice noodles are kinda dry and oil. Sadly, bf doesn't like it, but I took all the beef LMAO. AND he took half of my spicy pork noodle!! (THIS IS HOW AMAZING THEIR NOODLES "LA MEIN" IS)

Second visit: We got the lamb noodle, and yes the soup and noodles came out just like what we've expected it. Im craving their noodles from now on LOL. 

All in all, this is a very good noodle place to try if you're craving noodles like me. Will definietly come back to try the other stuff.

PS: they accept cards and take out. no wifi. good for groups of 3-5 people.
author: Kalum Z.

description:
This place is relatively new and its growing pains are pretty evident. We were the first to be seated with the wave of hungry dinner patrons, but it was obvious that the restaurant was completely overwhelmed. Waiters would ask already seated guests to swap tables in order to accommodate other tables.  Food came out slowly and was either lukewarm or bland. 

Case in point, my combo seafood noodle. I love hand pulled noodles, so +1 for that. The noodles themselves were thick, not too chewy, and super long. The dish featured little pieces of squid, conch, and shrimp. It was a nice mix, however, they were all incredibly briny in taste. It was as if they were taken fresh out of the ocean and thrown straight in. Don't get me wrong, I like my seafood fresh, but not that fresh. Also, the broth was heavily flavored with white pepper salt.

As for the lamb noodle, it also featured handpulled noodles along with a bed of vegetables (celery, carrots, tomatoes) and little bits of lamb. The lamb was awesomely tender, but the pieces came few and far between bites. I guess I shouldn't expect so much from a dish under $7...but I do. Or at least my taste buds do.

We also ordered pork/shrimp/chives dumplings. They came out looking like they had been sitting nearly 10 minutes.

All in all, I have no plans to come back soon.

By the way, they didn't have a doorknob on their unisex bathroom...literally a hole in the door. So pee fast.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I started to write a tip, but with the length of it, I decided to write a review. A few important things to point out: 

(1) They only take CARDS for purchases OVER $25. 

(2) The HOT SAUCE is delicious and very SPICY; more like pureed peppers (not the dry chili peppers in oil). 

(3) BEEF PANCAKE is not synonymous to the Beef Roll. Other restaurants call it the beef pancake (e.g. across the street), something that looks like a burrito. But my fault for not realizing that's not the name here. The beef pancake is tasty though, it's a thick green onion pancake cut into fours and deep fried. 
 
(4) The hand pulled laimein NOODLES are good quality, but I did not expect the spicy beef noodle soup to taste the way it did. It tasted more like a tom yum soup, SPICY and SOUR. I would not be ordering that dish again since it's not my palate preference... Would prefer the noodles in a different broth. I only came in here as I am on a quest to look for laimein closest to the kind I've had in China. 

(5) PAN FRIED DUMPKINGS are also not what I expected. The consistency is more like a pan fried BAO (BUN). A bit disappointing as there are 6 to one order. 

I may only visit again to try their noodles outside the soup. 

(6) The SERVICE is absent minded as she will frequently forget to get napkins, glasses of water, bowls as she goes back and forth. Service isn't good, but I gave her a break as she was the only one working the floor that night.
author: Angela L.

description:
Went here because a friend told me they have really good Xinjiang style Chicken and decent home-made dumplings. 

Waited about 15min before being seated at a Sunday at 7pm, we(2 ppl) ordered a serving of Xi'hu lamp dumpling, spicy beef tripe and the Xinjiang style Chicken which turned out to be plenty for us, we boxed the remaining chicken and dumplings in the end. 

Beef tripe and lamp dumplings were served way faster than the chicken, they are decent. And we waited for 15min for the chicken, but oh boy, it was worth it. the texture was very tender, the flavor is well balanced. I loved it and given my background of Xi'an, I think it is very authenticate.

In the end, we ordered four diff types of dumplings 20*4 togo.
author: Cheng C.

description: The dumplings and noodles are very authentic! The price is very decent! You got lots of portion! But the service was not so good!
author: Li L.

description: I would give this place minus 5 stars if I could. Service was very rude, tardy, and inefficient. Food sucks. Combination of bad food and bad service.
author: Joelle K.

description: YUM! This place is SO cheap for such GREAT food! The portions are really big too! We got 12 great pork and chive dumplings for just $6. Definitely get the noodle soups with hand pulled and freshly made noodles, and I recommend any dumpling dish. Sure it's loud, and service isn't too friendly but it makes it feel just like China. I got the Chicken Noodle with tasty chicken and deliciously chewy noodles. The soup was actually kind of tasty as well, because it was not too salty and had a lot of chicken flavor. The only thing I didn't like about this experience is that I would keep slipping down the booth seating, but that all got fixed when I moved the table closer to myself!
author: Brandon D.

description:
We ordered celery dumpling and beef pancake then added dumpling (pork & shrimp) with noodle after words.

The dumpling tasted fresh and a little on the salty side. Beef pancake was a little in the greasy side. Our biggest mistake was to add the dumpling with noodle soup! It took them long time to make it. I had to rush them several times. Honestly, the quickest meal to cook is noodle and dumpling. And I not sure why it took them so long to make the order. So the excuse that I was given was that add on order will need to wait after the rest of the other orders are made! Most of the restaurant will prepare the add on first so they can let the customers finish and go. 

As I'm typing this review, I'm still waiting patiently for my order!
author: Jaylene L.

description:
I am from Shandong, China. They made the exactly same taste as the best food in my hometown. I gona visit again defenitely 

must try their dumplin
author: David W.

description:
These guys knocked it out of the park.

Wok Mongolian Beef was literally the best beef I've ever had. I'm used to that bad east coast chinese food where ordering beef is guaranteed to be rubbery. This was perfectly tender and had absolutely amazing flavor. Huge portion, tons of great veggies.

Also had pork scallion dumplings. They were good. Not next level, but good. Again, the portion was huge. I expected 4 to 6 dumplings like the average dim sum place. Nah, this was like a dozen. It was WORK getting that plate empty with two of us.

Service was slow but I wasn't in a hurry, so it's all good.

Really though. Get the mongolian beef. Super nice prices too. Almost everything is under 8 bucks, and with the portions as big as they are? Gotta do it.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This place is good, noodles, dumplings, nice staff. Don't try the order online option it doesn't work, call in. 

Overall very decent option for dinner.
author: Jon K.

description: It's poor rating isn't out of nowhere. I went there and ordered those "popular" dishes. None of it is good and I promise I am not a picky person on food. I went there because it offers Xinjiang style chicken, its one of my fav dish. And it turned out to be totally a disappointment. The dish looks fully cooked and got the right sautéd color, yet it tasted totally plain. I couldn't tell there's any different for the flavor of the chicken and the potato, except the texture :( The size of the food is good though, but the chief wasted the gradients. If you're looking for real Xinjiang style chicken, definitely PASS on this one. The taste is not even close!
author: Meimei M.

description:
The price here is pretty attractive. 
Got Marinated pork in baked bun(rou jia mo)and 
pork&cabbage dumplings. They didn't taste very good (I am not saying that they were bad;however,I mean I had better baked buns and dumplings in other restaurants.
The service is good and I will come back for some noodles next time:)
author: Rila C.

description:
Since it's on Taraval, parking is never too horrible. Lately, they've been starting to get popular (and rightfully so, their food is good!). I usually come here when I want Northern Chinese food fix (dumpling or noodles) and don't really feel like driving/waiting for Kingdom of Dumpling.

The venue fits about .. 30-40 people? It's not a first-date type place for sure, but I don't come to expect that from Chinese restaurants anyway.

Prices are on-par with Kingdom of Dumpling and in terms of dumplings.. they are very comparable, so YES, they are really good. The skin isn't too doughy or thick and they're juicy. I've also gotten the beef noodles a couple of times and the beef is super tender and flavorful and the noodles have a nice bite to them and isn't too thick or doughy (hand-pulled, yee!)
author: Emily C.

description:
The people working there only speak mandarin so it is somewhat hard to communicate. My friends and I figured out whatever we wanted on the menu, we point. 

My friends and I came strolling in around 9pm on a Friday night. The restaurant apparently closes at 9:30 and we had no idea. One of the waitresses were trying to tell us that they were closing soon & if we wanted to order, we should order now. All of my friends and I except one couldn't understand what she was saying. Luckily, one person out of our group was the translator.

The food was pretty mediocre for Chinese. The dumplings were nothing special. The noodles here are apparently hand-pulled. The portions were huge depending on what you ordered. So definitely a bang for your buck.
author: Kathleen U.

description:
I've experienced bad service many times, but this is a whole new level.. Such a shame since my gf and I really like Chinese food. 

When we arrived, it was really booked so we thought, "hey this may be good". As soon as we were seated deep in the hallway towards the restroom, I kinda had a bad feeling but still stayed positive on ordering the food. 

We ordered the following:

-Beef Pancake Rolls - Pretty good but I've had better.

-Leek Pancake - Meh, I wouldn't recommend it. Should have gotten something better.

-Shrimp and Chive Dumplings - The first two bites were not bad, but it gets tiring and I lost my appetite when I reached this dish (you will know why in the next paragraph) 

-Zha Jiang Mian - It's good but again, I lost my appetite later on and couldn't finish it, which is rare for me.

The main reason why I was really really really annoyed by this place is because there's a stupid metal circuit box right next to my face right on the wall at our table. Every few minutes, a different restaurant worker will come to our table to open the circuit box and hit switches. Every time they open the box, it's right in front of my face and my gf saw the insides of the box, which is super dusty. I don't appreciate them hovering the circuit box door over our food 20 times (yes I counted), it really made me lose my appetite. One of the workers, middle age man just slapped my shoulder and told me to move so he can open the circuit box. 

My feedback is, either they remove that table right next to the circuit box or they should pay for a more efficient way of using energy. This is not how customers should be treated, they really have to fix their attitudes, especially when it's something they are doing wrong. The food could have been good but I really lost my appetite with the constant interruptions at our table with that stupid circuit box they keep opening and closing. 

In conclusion, I will never ever come back, nor would I recommend this place to anyone. If you want real good Chinese food on Taravel, I highly recommend House of Pancake or Dumpling Kitchen. Or even freaking drive down to China North Dumpling on Noreiga for better Shandong food. It's really a shame since I wanted to like this place..
author: Victor Q.

description:
Uhhh. Who ever gave this anything but 5 is crazy. 

Get the Hui Lamb Noodle Soup. Best noodle soup in my life.
author: Brian G.

description:
I brought a bunch of visitors here after touring Treasure Island. ...

We ordered all kinds of stuff...

Beef pancake...it was ok

Xiao long bao....don't bother...skip it

Fried tofu...good

Lamb with all kinds of noodles....not for me but most liked it....

19.99 chicken potatoes with thick noodles....we requested a tad spicy...that was very good.....enough for 3-4 easily......this dish was the best.....well worth a try
author: Leslie Y.

description: We love this pale so much that travel regularly from Berkeley to eat here. Our picture is up on the wall because we probably ate out weight in soup dumplings here during the years. Everything is delicious. Our favorites are the soup dumplings ( xia long bao), the lamb dumplings, the pork shrimp and chive dumplings, beef pancake, fungus and cucumber salad, bean noodles, peanut noodles. So so tasty. We always take home frozen dumplings with us :)
author: Bella H.

description: Decent food but beware of inflated (and arbitrary) pricing on to-go orders. The past two times I called in an order they tried to charge me more than the prices listed on the menu.
author: Collin C.

description:
To my surprise,  I found out that the wontons and dumplings are frozen.  I watched our waitress pull our order out from the two freezers they have.  Anyone with a good palete will tell you frozen food taste different and our food did.  If I wanted frozen, I would have made it at home.  First this tells me they don't sell enough to keep it fresh and secondly, they don't care its frozen.  Bags and bags of wonton and dumplings are stored in the freezer.  Don't waste your time and money here because its not fresh.

I gave it two stars instead of one because of the clear soup...it really was a one star because its frozen food.  The soup was a little plain and hopefully not full of MSG....a little salt and a few more pork bones would greatly help spark up the soup.

Million dollar question....will I go back.  NOPE...NOT FOR FROZEN FOOD!!!!!!!!!
author: MickYee M.

description:
This place is the best dumpling place in town, PERIOD!!!! We got it recommended by a Chinese friend and it quickly became ours, and our friends and family's favorite! The Xiao long bao (Shanghai soup dumplings), the pork- shrimp- chive dumplings and the lamb dumplings are my favorites along with the cold peanut noodles(E1), cucumber salad with fungus and dry sauteed green beans with chilis. 
The chicken feet dish is awesome too but its big feeds two or more! All the noodles are hand stretched in the front of you! Whaaattt???!!!!yup that authentic  buy some frozen dumplings to go because its a great quick dinner on week nights or to give as a gift to your foodie friends
author: Kriszta K.

description: The taste has become disgustingly bad since they have opened and let alone the worst service even for a Chinese restaurant. Arrogant waitress and cooks that refused to own up to anything. Do not eat here
author: Alex S.

description:
I would give a zero rating if yelp allows. The services are not acceptable. We got to the restaurant quarter before 12pm and the restaurant wasn't even a full house. We ordered 5 items and only 3 appetizers came after 20 min. And our 2 bowls of noodle soups never came, we waited for 40 min and asked where are our noodle soups. They told us they are still making our noodle soup. How long does it take to make 2 bowls of noodle soups ??? Apparently it took them more 40 min  just to get started.  It is ridiculous! ! We canceled the noodle soups and asked for the bills.

Also, no apology from the server and whatsoever. Worst customer service, me and my family will never go back. I won't recommend the restaurant to another people as well. This restaurant looks like a joke.
author: Stacy L.

description:
$35 minimum if you want to use card to pay so I would advice people to bring cash if not coming in a big party. Place is also pretty small and crowded. 

The food was okay but the noodles were pretty much stuck together and it was hard to mix it with the sauce since it was a huge block. 

The servers did not even come by to check up on us and by the way... they reuse their tea kettle. There were 4 tea bags in our tea kettle and our tea poured out clear like water even when we left it to steep for a while to see if the tea would get stronger but NOPE. The tea still came out clear like water with a slight yellow tint.
author: Michele M.

description:
I'm surprise this place only have 3 stars. Taste is 5 stars, but overall four stars because of the setting. CASH ONLY.

It is all about their hand pulled noodles and dumplings here. When we ate the appetizer noodle dish, we can tell that the noodles were definitely hand pulled, not by machines. If the taste of the noodles did not make it apparent, there was a young man pulling the noodle dough in the kitchen. The hand pulled noodles are more chewy and I like my noodles chewy over soft ones.

We also ordered black bean sauce noodles. The noodles were delicious but the sauce was lacking . I prefer hella sauce on my noodles but they only put enough to cover the noodles. The sauce would have been better if they put more vegetable and tofu/or meat pieces into it.

The dumplings and xiao long baos were delicious. I love their hot sauce too.

The restaurant is really small and cramped. It does not have a waiting area. It is not stroller friendly. This family was waiting with their huge stroller in the main (and only) walk way in the restaurant and basically blocked the only route to leave the restaurant. FIRE HAZARD!! The staff members should've caught that and told them to wait outside. We went during busy lunch hour on a saturday so it was hard to get the waiters attention when needed and we had to wait longer (which is expected), but we had to wait an abnormally long time for this one dish - which is the pan fried leek pancake.
author: Shirley M.

description:
It took an hour to get your take-out... Waited half hour for xioalongboa and got informed that they forgot to cook it... 

Waiter is not friendly to answer question.
author: Min-cheng H.

description:
I don't understand the low reviews of this place.  The place has excellent value authentic northern Chinese food.  Portions are huge and the prices are very cheap for the kind of quality (handmade) food that is expected.   12 pieces of handmade dumplings for $5.95??  And they are open on Christmas day!

Spicy pork noodle (aka dan dan mein) was very delicious.  The lamb noodle was perfectly cooked with delicious pieces of flavorful lamb.  Chives dumplings were good as well.

-1 star for overcooking the handmade noodles (I like more "qq" in my noodles). 

Solid choice for this area.
author: Addison C.

description:
I came here with my parents for a Sunday lunch. Fortunately we got there before 12p and there was no line yet, but shortly after a crowd started to build up outside. There's another Chinese pancake place down the street, but this place has more seating, which is nice when you don't feel like being crammed which you eat. Don't get me wrong, it's still a small restaurant, just not tiny.  

This time we ordered shanghai dumplings, the beef wrap, tendons and the zha jiang mian (soybean paste with hand pulled noodles). The dumplings were decent. The beef wrap was delicious, the cucumbers add this freshness to the bite. (Their beef pancake is also good, just a different taste as it is fried and is just beef). While I usually favor tripe, the tendon was in this spicy sauce, which made it so hard to stop eating. My leaves happy.
author: Natalie B.

description: Didn't really find this place all that great. Ordered a couple of dishes here: Xiao Long Bao, Beef pancakes, some noodle I forgot the name of. The XLB weren't really special, definitely had better elsewhere. The noodles were like eating a softer version of stir fried rice cakes but it lacked flavor. Apparently the noodles are hand pulled. I didn't really taste a huge difference except that the noodles were chewier than normal. They were also really thick too. The beef pancakes were super oily and salty. The dishes were affordable so at least I don't feel too bad for getting mediocre food...
author: Benita M.

description: The only good thing here I'd say is the beef wrap. Everything else is just ok. Also, everyone gets the chicken dish for $20.99. I tried it tonight and it's not good. It's a big plate with chopped up chicken and tons of bones. Definitely not worth the cost and taste isn't good. I'd be happier with chicken chow mein or something. Maybe it's an acquired taste but    not for me.
author: Larry L.

description:
Typically my friends and I order the DaPanJi (Chicken with chilis, handmade noodles, bell peppers, and potatoes) and the Xian Cold Noodles. The chicken might take a little longer to prepare, so my friend calls ahead of time occasionally so that it  would be ready when we get there.

Its not a very big place, so I get there close to when they open to beat the lines.

Service is typical of a Chinese restaurant,  you call them over when you need someone.
author: Geraldine C.

description:
I have eaten here a few times in the past and it was generally good. The dumplings were good, the soup noodles a bit hit and miss.

Sitting here and writing this now, I'm not much inclined to come back. The service always tests my patience as asking a fork for the kids requires persistence (just grab me a damn fork already) and tonight I gave up after asking both waiters and got it myself.

The food is okay. Their dumplings are still good - try the pork with chives. Their spicy beef noodle soup is actually too spicy and I used to just plow through it, but now they're skimping on the beef slices. The noodles are homemade and they're still good and chewy, however. The beef chow fun is riddled with cabbage and sprout fillers and not much beef. Their fried tofu is good, but it's usually good everywhere. There's a cold noodle dish (can't recall the name) that looks like a gray pile of dead noodles, but surprisingly good. The beef pancake is an oily and salty mess-avoid it.

Anyways, after tonight I'm probably not going to come back. It's not that the food is terrible, but the service and food is not enough to make me want to come here when there are better places to go. House of Pancake up the block is much better, so rather than bounce between the two as I had in the past, it's just HoP from here on out. 2.5 stars.

On a side note, this one time we were having dinner here, this big huge fight erupted in the kitchen. I think it's the husband and wife fighting and it was loud. Went on for like 5 minutes and everyone in the restaurant just blinked their eye, not knowing what to do. Was funny. Unprofessional, but funny.
author: Bor C.

description:
YUM! Cash Only. Small place. Cheap for amount of food they give. Very flavorful. Not a lot of vegetarian choices, but they have just a few. Would definitely go back again! 

WARNING! Their service sucks, even if you can speak Mandarin.
author: Cindy C.

description:
4 stars for their hand made noodles which i consider a traditional chinese art.  Something about seeing a 15 year old looking boy pull noodles to master his family's secret teachings pulled on the strings in my heart.  Ok sorry if that sounded racist but I'm chinese so its ok.

however, if youre looking for cantonese style chinese, which is almost 80% of the type of chinese food you normally eat, this is NOT the place.  So therefore, stay away from the beef chowfun (it wont be what you expect) and all other typical chinese dishes you order at a fast take out or dimsum/bbq/noodlehouse/fancydinner chinese place.  you have been forewarned.
author: Vince L.

description: Love their food. Service, though, can be slow during busy hours, especially during dinner hours. I've been here a couple times and have only been pleased with one waiter, who provided great service (he even asked if we wanted to refill our tea, all the while running around serving and taking orders). I guess you can say that my experiences seem to improve with the number of visits. Their food is definitely good, especially their dumplings and hand-pulled noodles.
author: Sara T.

description:
You come here for their famous hand made noodles... Clearly earning them 5 stars as they are soft as the baby bottom.

Carb king and queens this us your place!

However their quality of everything else is subpar! That's why the heavy ding...
Roasted beef in spicy beef stew is chewy and hard, not soft and supple I have found in many other places. Tendons cooked over short period of time and hard as a rock

Their dumplings fillings are also minimal

So if you care about noodle fix.. This works..
Everything else is mediocre at best

I had to wait in long lines to get in on a Saturday 2pm
author: David H.

description: I wish I could give a no-star review.  Me and my friends have been here for couple times, every time the same dishes taste and ingredients are different, the people are working there are not friendly at all, dishes are dirty. This time we even find something like gum (rubber looking) in one of the egg and tomato dish. And the Shanghai pork dumplings are not fresh, smelled and tasted rotten. We will never come back again.
author: Summer B.

description: Love it. The Shiao Long Bao is better than Ding Tai Fung in Valley Fair. The noodle soups aren't overly salty and didn't have a trace of MSG.
author: Jayce T.

description:
I normally don't write bad reviews. However, after eating here tonight and reading all the yelp reviews (dating back to 2012), I felt compelled to warn others about the service. The owner has made no attempt to improve service since 2012. She's very friendly and nice but her workers look very unhappy. I wonder if she's even paying a living wage. 

The food is hit or miss. Some dishes were pretty decent tasting. Despite the decent dishes, I would never eat there again because of the service. It's not worth spending my money and time when its stressful dealing with the staff. 

We had to ask for everything a few times (high chair, extra bowls for soup). We had a 2 year old with us and they never gave us a fork or spoon for her. Instead, they gave her a cup for tea and chopsticks. They seemed irritated every time we asked for anything. 

A couple, seated at 4 top, had been waiting for their food 30 mins when they were asked to move another table. They threw a shit fit and started to yell at the waiter in front of the restaurant. 

Skip this place. It's not worth the yelp hype. Go to one of the other places on Taravel so you can actually enjoy your food in a less stressful environment.
author: Kar Y.

description:
Wow- we got the Xinjiang- style chicken dish and it was AMAZING. It came on a huge dish, and the food was piled high- chicken, chili, potatoes, noodles, bell pepper, ginger- it is a big dish that can easily feed 4 people. So good! 

We also ordered the dumplings- which were really good- we got the pork and spinach dumplings, and the chicken and napa dumplings. It was perfectly done- the skin was thick and yummy, too!

The noodles are hand pulled here so we tried the black bean noodles- excellent!

But, it's a tiny restaurant so the wait for a table can be long. Also, they squeezed too many tables into their small area, so the people in the next table were really close to us- on both sides!
author: Charissa N.

description:
Sure, there are quite a few Shanghai noodle and dumpling shops that reside on Taraval street... but what makes this place different from the rest?  

Oodles & oodles of hand-pulled noodles... and when I say oodles & oodles of noodles... I mean it... like long, long strands of never-ending noodles... so many noodles that by the time you get midway... u'll notice that there are still HELLAEVA bunch left! 

FOOD & TASTE:
"Spicy Pork Noodle" ...comes with ground pork, bean sprouts, spicy chilies, and choice of white or green noodles.  Taste?  Not bad... flavor kind of dissipates... I've had better in Vegas.  Wow, did I just say that?  :-/

"Pork & Vegetable Wonton w/ Noodle" ...is just what it is, wontons in noodle soup with bok choy, and choice of white or green noodles.  I mistakenly ordered this... thinking it would be Pork & Vegetable Noodle soup, which I later found out (by reading the Chinese) that I should have ordered the "Muster Pork Noodle" instead.  :-/  Taste?  Well, I really enjoyed the chewiness of the noodles!  Hand pulled noodles... can't beat that!

"Shanghai Steam Pao" ...funny, I've never seen "STEAM PAO" for XLB.  Apparently, they even have a sign on the wall too, haha!  So as for taste... Kingdom of Dumpling still tops the winner of XLB on Taraval st.  The steam pao here were pipping hot, full of flavor, but what happened to my soup?  :-/

CONVENIENCE: *** [CASH only... sucks, for Wells Fargo customers, but BofA & Chase are just up the block.  Parking can be easy... metered or 2hr. residential spots.]
AMBIANCE: **** [Small resto, open space, high ceilings... my sis mentioned that it looks just like the ramen place, only thing different is the food.]
SERVICE: **** [They must have read the previous Yelp reviews, cuz the gal was consistently checking up on us... ready to order, any questions, refill on tea, and boxes to go.]
PRICE:  $  [$4.95 for (6) XLB, $5.95-$6.95 for noodle soups.]
OVERALL: ***/* [3.5-stars... Not bad... not great... but does the job.]

NOTE: Ask for some scissors to cut the never-ending noodles... cuz slurping ain't gonna cut them for u!  
Nuff said.

[#14 of 100 YELP CHALLENGE 2013]
author: Lily Y.

description:
Yummy hole in the wall place with awesome beef tendon (hand-pulled) noodle soup.  Oh, that was heavenly.

This place isn't fancy, and don't expect great service, but they serve northern Chinese comfort food that makes me wish I could move back to San Francisco.

I definitely recommend their hand-pulled noodle soup, which are perfectly toothsome.  Add a little dollop of the hot sauce, and I could live happily on this forever.  

I also tried the crab meat dumplings (pretty good wrapper, but I didn't find the filling especially distinctive), the green onion pancakes (wonderfully greasy and crispy), and the Xian noodles (interesting, but I don't know if I'd order it again, I'd rather have the hot dishes).

We had to wait forever for refills of hot water for the tea or for the bill.  Luckily, I didn't need change, because we probably would have run out of time on the meter.

Btw, they are cash only.  There is a nearby BofA ATM.
author: michelle l.

description: Kinda crowded but the food was served quickly.  Hand pulled noodles is to die for, texture was great.  Dumpling was wonderful, not soggy!!
author: Wailun Eugene W.

description: Worst service ever. Waited 45 minutes and our entree still didn't come so we left angrily. They are way understaffed and the wait staff is incompetent. We were completely ignored and people who arrived after us got served before us. Never again.
author: Suzan L.

description:
In the past couple months, whenever I had a craving for northern Chinese food on a cold day, Shandong Deluxe always popped into my mind.  Why? Because it's affordable, filling, and warms me up from the inside.  My perpetual favorite is the Xinjiang noodle although I think all of the noodles dishes I've tried here are great too. The dumplings here are better than the famous dumpling place 10 blocks down Taraval although opinions may vary.  Since I like spicy food, the spicy beef tendon is a great starter dish. 

Depending on who's working, the service and English may be so-so but it's definitely not a deal-breaker. 

Cash only!
author: Renee L.

description:
One star for service and 4 stars for food (previous visit). Ordered a rather simple dish, spicy beef noodle. 

Restaurant was near empty when I got here, 30-35 minutes later the place is near full and have yet to get my noodles, even though everyone else has been served.  

I was given tea (albeit, Lipton tea) and told "it's coming". I'm just gonna leave.
author: Alejandro C.

description:
Returned here recently, again because the Pancake House across the street was closed (on a Wednesday?). The dining room was full but the staff cleared off the table where normally to-go orders are put and offered us it. It happened to be next to the breaker panel, and three times the staff needed to interrupt us to reset a circuit. These amounted to a comedy of errors rather than a serious disappointment, as the food was very good. 
We ordered the freshly made pork and spinach dumplings, onion pancakes and a beef stew--all of which were wonderful and delicious. This place has been redeemed in my opinion.
author: Brian G.

description:
We arrived a little before 12pm on a Sunday, wrote our name down for a table of 4. Waited maybe about 15 minutes for a table, not too bad at all.

We ordered a lot of food for 4 people:
beef pancake: beefy, I prefer this over the green onion pancake, maybe due to the fact it has meat
green onion pancake: crispy
black bean sauce noodles: tasty and very saucy
beef tendon noodles: tasted like something I could make at home
pan fried dumplings: these were huge
pork and napa cabbage dumplings: ordinary but good

I believe everything was homemade, all from scratch, the wrappers/noodles/fillings...

I think we could have ordered 4 things and had been satisfied, maybe one less dumpling and pancake. I think it was about $11/person, not bad for the amount of food we ate.
author: Kylie L.

description: As a Chinese we are happy with the food here, price here and the services here! Will go back for sure!
author: Becca B.

description: This place is delicious! We had fungus with cucumber, beef dumplings and the spicy beef soup and the seafood, pork and chicken noodle soup. The broths in each soup were fragrant and flavorful, the fungus and steamed dumplings were perfectly seasoned and delicious. The staff is attentive and helpful. Wonderful!
author: Susan C.

description:
Why do people say cash only? Maybe they changed policies? I had dinner there tonight and paid with a VISA.

I like getting either their Spicy Beef Noodle or their Beef Noodle. I think the soup might be the same, except for some hot sauce in the spicy one. The soup is very good and tasteful.

Their noodles are made in house, and because I prefer firm noodles I like what they offer. I don't like how their noodles clump together when you first get them but it's very easy to just loosen them up before eating. 

I also really enjoy their napa cabbage dumplings. I always order this when I go. It's a good balance of veggies and meat. You can taste the napa cabbage, but it's not all you taste/eat. 

Service is typical of Chinese restaurants. They don't really spare smiles, but to me they do their best to serve their customers.
author: Bonnie C.

description:
A good place with handmade Chinese ramen and dumplings. I had beef stew noodle soup here. I like heavier broth so it didn't match my taste but I think it is still good. And lighter broth is supposedly healthier. I totally will come back and try other items.

The decoration is odd here though. It is a Chinese restaurant but the art on the wall is Japanese.
author: George C.

description: Yuck. Don't eat here. Food is so gross.  Found a quarter inch of oil floating on the bottom of my beef chow fun.
author: W W.

description: Gummy homemade noodle, soothing hot soup, delicious dumplings...what not to love about this place. It gets crowded most night so come early! Service has always been good to us. Must order their homemade noodle and dumplings! 5/5 stars for this place!
author: Brian K M.

description:
Shandong Deluxe replaces Ramen Doraku in name only. the decor remains. (a  ramen doraku nameplate is still up in the back).

specialites; (stated on front window)
-shandong dumplings
-shandong hand pull noodles
-xiao long bao
-won ton/noodle soup
-small plates (appetizers, northern style)
-shandong bread? 
-more listed  unsure of translation

eats:
fish steam dumplings (12/6.95)
-some fish taste with chives, dumplings huge like potstickers
-not a dumplings fan, so just ok.
lamb noodle (6.95)
-tender lamb pieces, very  tender noodle, not chewy, not al dente
-broth had lamb,  star anise, szechwan mustard, and msg flavorings
-didn't have that hand pull noodles chewiness
food: 3.5 stars

.takeouts:
-service not a problem.
-not many tables, fills up fast.
-semi-open kitchen, lady in back making dumplings
-portions large. taste ok (3 stars), good value (4 stars)
author: Victor G.

description:
After reading the reviews on Yelp, I had to lower my expectations just a little bit.  We decided to eat here after biking.  Got here around 8ish and waited about 40 minutes- more like an hour when you're super hungry and watching everyone else eat.  

I made a bathroom run so I have no idea what the names of the dishes are called so I'll try my best to describe them...or copy and paste from yelp =P

Tripe salad- "Not the fuzzy type" that my bf was expecting but overal very good.  
Xinjiang noodles with beef- This dish was ok.  The noodles were good but the strands were continously long- it was quite a struggle splittling this 4 ways.
Beef Pancake-  "Oooh, whats that dish?  It looks like a pancake stuffed with beef"... "It's a beef pancake" Duh!!  The outside was greasy but crispy.  It looks burnt but boy, it was good.
Spicy Beef Noodle- Big portion, right amount of spice, a little lemony.  Again, the infinite noodles made it difficult to split but this time we were smart- ask for scissors!
Green Onion Pancake- super thin.

I was surprised by the low reviews.  I thought this place was pretty decent.  We could've passed on the noodles with beef and the green onion pancake but at least we tried it.  

Very inexpensive. Very.
author: Linda N.

description:
My curiosity piqued.  How would yet another, a third, dumpling spot on Taraval fare?  Apparently, not so well.

As Yelper Bri Y. mentioned, ShanDong Deluxe replaced Ramen Doraku in name and menu, but not in decor.  I found the menu hilarious, since there was handwritten scribble all over ours, crossing out misspellings and updating options.  At least someone is helping to proof the menus?  Although shouldn't this be done prior to printing?  But I digress.

So the food....in summary, lacking in flavor. Here's what the FH and I ordered:

- Salt Pepper Tofu $5.95 - super bland
- Onion Pan Cake Egg Wrap $5.95 - I could do without the egg next time (well, actually, doubt there'll be a next time), and the onion pancake itself was limp and virtually tasteless
- XLBs $4.95 (for six) - sad. These XLBs were small, shriveled, and nearly soupless, not plump and juicy like I had hoped for
- Spicy Beef Sauced Noodle $6.95 - chewy noodles were actually pretty good, but the broth had zero flavor and just tasted spicy

Service was fine, and we were told we needed to pay cash because the restaurant would be closing soon.  No problem, but if you are closing, why are you still accepting walk-ins?  Also, for being a new restaurant, why are your condiment containers already caked with dried sauce?  Not impressed.

Super disappointing and unsatisfying meal.  Next time I'm sticking to the other two similar joints down the street.
author: Mel T.

description: Always get the Pork dumplings with Napa and Beef Chow Fun. Portions are very generous and super tasty! I haven't been disappointed yet.
author: Julian T.

description: First time I came here it was for the noodles. Saw the guy in the window hand pulling them and immediately thought FRESH! Then while enjoying the outstanding flat flour ones, I saw it! It was "love at first sight." It looked really sexy. A mountain of chicken, potatoes, bell peppers etc, on top of big fat No.3 type flour noodles, all swimming in a deep red pungent sauce, with 100 small red Sichuan chili peppers for company! Wow!! It was called "Xinjiang Chicken" and it was gigantic. (And not cheap at $20.99.) But I knew at first sight, that I had to have it! Visit #2, "Xinjiang Chicken please!" After a short wait, it came. As I dug in, I closed my eyes and there it was, i was in the Urumqi main market, The Erdaoqiao Market, the Silk Road, the smell of grilled kebabs in the air. Handmade pita bread being rolled around me. Middle Eastern type music wafting through the market. Asian faces with strong middle eastern lines all around. The shopowner beckoning me to come into his shop in Turkish, and to try his special "Xinjiang Chicken," and as I went in and sat down, and he brought it to me, my eyes opened to the taste of fire and cardamom in my mouth.  It was so good, I almost started yelling in Turkish (the language of the Uigher minority who inhabit Xinjiang,) "mashallah, Öldüm ve cennete gitti ettik" (oh god! I've died and went to heaven!) but I didn't, to keep the Cantonese people around me eating this delicious shandong food, from thinking I was crazier than they already thought, (about a white guy eating a 100 pepper dish, smiling and howling.) So, like to travel to faraway, exotic places? Yes? But you don't have the time and money? Can I interest you in a trip to Xinjiang? It only costs $20.99 and 2 hours max. If you go, don't forget to try the "Xinjiang Chicken," and don't forget  to hit me up afterwards and I'll tell you how to say "delicious, thank you" in Uighur, (Turkish.)
author: George F.

description: I came here for the dumplings but left wanting to try more noodles. A good sign that I'll be back in the future. Their Pork and Napa and Chicken and Corn dumplings were good and actually different from the other dumpling places I've reviewed around the Bay Area (Town, Kingdom, King, etc.). These dumplings seem to have a thicker skin, larger, and the filling is flavored differently. I normally like Pork and Napa over Chicken and Corn but it's the opposite here. There's a larger selection of dumplings here than most places too, including crab, fish, and different lamb combinations. I also tried their signature Xin Jian Chicken Noodle plate...which is huge and has to have at least a whole chicken in it. It's worth a try but it's more for 3-4 people and doesn't have much noodles in it since the noodles are huge, thick, wide styled noodles. The portion sizes here are pretty generous and if I were to come back, I'll be looking for more dumplings and one of their handmade noodle soups.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I'm torn.  The food is good, but the service is horrendous!  I'll be nice and give 3 stars for now.  

I was excited when Shandong opened in the Sunset, because I thought it was related to Shan Dong in Oakland Chinatown that I've heard so much about from friends.  Both places have hand pulled noodles and fresh made dumplings, but I don't think the restaurants are related.  

The place was packed on a Tuesday night, and the bf and I stood there unacknowledged as we waited for the next available table.  We watched in puzzlement and worry as the staff was visibly frazzled and the diners were either waiting for food or trying to get the staff's attention.  After 5 minutes we were finally greeted with a "please sit" and some hot tea.  

The menu is divided nicely into soups, noodles, dumplings, etc.  However, unless you know what Sam Sun, or Xinjiang style, or Hanamaki mean, it is difficult to pick what to order.  There are no descriptions for any of the items, which is a huge mistake because people generally want to know what they're about to eat.  This, along with the fact that the place could barely function with 18 diners, was very unsettling.  But then the food came, and it was okay.

The onion pancake was crisp and chewy at the same time.  The vegetarian dumplings were the perfect thickness and consistency, and filled with edamame and tofu (I think).  The noodles (I don't even known what we ordered) were the best hand pulled noodles I've had in the city.  They had a great flavor and chew, and were in a light, spicy, garlic broth with plump shrimp and cabbage.  The house chili sauce enhanced everything, and I was lost in spicy, chewy, deliciousness.  

That is until we were done eating, and it was an effort to try to get the staff's attention so that we could pack our leftover dumplings, pay, and be out of there.  

I want to go back, but only when they are not busy and overwhelmed.  Hopefully they'll learn the ropes of running and operating a restaurant soon, because the food is pretty damn good and it would be a shame if they don't improve their service.
author: Sandy K.

description:
This place was okay..nothing really special.

The best dish would be the spicy beef noodle. The noodle are all hand made and it really taste so fresh. 

The green pancakes were pretty good too just a bit greasy. 

Everything else was just ordinary. I got the veggie shrimp dumplings and it felt like it was microwave. 

The place is super small and gets pretty crowded during lunch time. 

The price itself is cheap and if you looking for a quick fix...I GUESS you can come here. 

Overall, i have experienced better.
author: Adam J.

description:
If you're craving tasty, hand-pulled noodles then this place is a pretty good option.

Ordered the:

Xianjian(sp?) cold noodles - it's saucy with a slight kick to it. For some reason it tastes very much like a Vietnamese dish.

Xiao long bao - decent, but the wrapper was a little too thick at the tip (that's what she said) for my liking. If I'm craving XLBs, I will stick to my go-to Dumpling Kitchen.

Beef stew noodle - broth was very flavorful and the hand-pulled noodles were fresh and delicious. The beef chunks were good, too, but there could've been more of it. Definitely a satiating meal on its own.

Beef wrap - I thought it was a bit bland but the wrap had a nice crisp to it.

For all 4 dishes the bill came out to be $26.50. I've had cheaper meals, but the pricing isn't too bad.
author: Tee C.

description:
So... I am always looking for a new place to eat near work.  On the sign it says ShanDong Deluxe, but their cards say ShanDong Delicacy.   At 230pm there were a few tables eating a late lunch.  They did not have take-out menus yet so I stood there and quickley decieded to play it safe with Beef Chow Fun and Xia Long Bao.  Overall the food was good.  Nothing to brag about.  

But as I was waiting a table received their order of Xinjiang Chicken Noodles and it looked tasty.  I asked the waitress to point the dish out on the menu and it was $19.99 and seemed like a good portion to split with 2-3 people. 

The place was small but very clean.  And had a health score in the mid 90's.

Im going to wait a little while and try again with my co-workers to get a better sence of their food.
author: Sheenie L.

description: The hand made noodles is very good.  Must have.  I come here often, maybe twice a month.
author: Jack L.

description:
This restaurant is small with very limited seating. Thankfully when we came, the line was relatively short and the turnover was quick.  We ordered the pan fried hand pulled noodles and soup dumplings.  I could see the noodles being handmade in the kitchen.  The noodles were chewy and tasty.  My only complaint was that it was on the greasy side.  The soup dumplings were flavorful and the hot sauce (condiment on the side of the table) made it taste even better.

The service was fast and friendly. Prices were affordable--but this establishment is CASH only.

We were super thirsty after eating here....must have been the MSG...
author: Janet E.

description:
I ordered lamb tonight, and the food was raw! It was red and chewy. 

I feel so upset and angry!
author: Lulu C.

description:
for a taste of Northern Chinese cooking in the Parkside, this is your best option. The dumplings are not quite as good as the Kingdom of dumplings down the street, but the other dishes worth mentioning are listed here:
1- lamb skewers with chili pepper flakes and cumin - excellent
2- xian cold noodle salad is wonderful house made broad noodles in a savory peanut sauce dressing. (sorry peanut allergy folks). this may be the star of the show at this restaurant. it's tossed table side by our server and if you are hungry, you should definitely order this one. or share one order with a friend.
3. persian cucumber salad here is wonderfully dressed and has a garlicky hint.
4- cold soy bean curd noodle salad. nearly every Northern Chinese restaurant has a version of this dish. but this one served here may be my favorite rendition. the soy bean curd noodles are an excellent sponge for the dressing. very refreshing
5- the chive pancakes with yam noodles are pan fried and are very tasty. I would recommend this dish for pancake fans from anywhere ..
NOT to be served with aunt jemima syrup, this is the Northern Chinese savory kind of street food. another version has  beef slices and green onions. one of my first personal experiences with this type of pancakes came from a food vendor on the streets of Beijing in 2007. the second time it was at of all places, inside of a WALMART in Beijing!
hm hm good.
JYW likes this place and the people are friendly.
by the way, the noodle dishes use noodles pulled by hand by the chefs on site. very chewy and great in a hot soup dish.
author: Jeff W.

description: Excellent food, cold noodles, hand pulled noodles and dimsum! Ive beeb here before. Its not even crowdy right now (monday at 5pm) but on most nights and wekeends expect a line and a 30min wait.
author: Pinky A.

description: Dumplings galore! Word to the wise, it's always better to get chopped ginger with your soy sauce & vinegar dipping sauce.
author: Dru C.

description:
What is everyone talking about that I did not get to experience?  I came with the parents over the weekend and by the end of the meal, we pretty much decided we would not be coming back anytime soon.  The following is what we ordered.

Xinjiang Noodle with Pork: I'll admit the noodles were good.  You can tell that they're hand-pulled.  The sauce and everything else?  Not impressed.

Pork and Corn Dumplings: Wrapping was too thick.  

Xiao Long Bao:  They forgot our order and so it came out towards the end of our meal.  Judging by the dumplings though, we definitely did not have high expectations.  The XLBs were weird.  They were almost like...pyramid shaped?  Some were punctured already so the soup had already leaked out.  Would not recommend it.

Beef Wrap: Ok.

Dry Cooked Chicken Wings: These were just not good.  There was no spice to it whatsoever, despite all the peppers on the plate.  (I guess it was just there for decoration?)  All I could really taste was this sweet and spicy sauce.  My sister likened it to the sauce you would find at Panda Express, but even worse.  The small-ish wings were served on this giant plate, which made it even sadder.  Man, I should have taken a picture.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Not much of an update but pretty much 2 years later my sister, brother and I found ourselves back here tonight--we laughed over how intense my last review was from our not-so-good previous experience!  Wowsa.  

Service is still lacking but the food today was ON POINT!  We'd definitely be back for the Mackerel Dumplings and the Wok Fried Napa Cabbage with dried shrimp (smells crazy dank but it's sooo legit and tastes good added inside dumplings!).
author: Nadia D.

description: everything i had here was good, but the highlights were the fresh noodles with just the right amount of bite, the xinjiang chicken
author: Long C.

description:
The food here is fantastic! Noodles and dumplings house made by hand?! Who knew you could find that in the Sunset? Keep in mind this is not Cantonese food that most sf natives (like me) are used to, this is Northern Chinese cuisine which has different flavors. I was not familiar with it and was hesitant as the place does not say extravagant - it says Authentic. So I asked our waitress, Carina, for recommendations.

Carina not only told us house favorites, she was able to describe how each item is prepared,  ingredients used,  type of sauce, etc. I was impressed & when the food came out it was even better than expected. I will definitely be back!  What really gives this place a five star rating (on top of all the above) is that it is a small,  local,  family run business with extremely honest employees. I accidentally left my purse behind filled with my wallet, my tablet, etc. and didn't realize until after my massage hours later. Not only was my tablet and my wallet still there, they kept safe in the back for me - and all my cash was still in it! I tried to give the father the cash, but he wouldn't take it. In the end I insisted to the waiter to give it to him. I'm amazed with their integrity as individuals and the pride they put in every dish. I highly recommend Shandong  Deluxe! 

Tip: Try the beef wrap, pork and chives dumplings, beef stew noodle (soup) & the pan fried dumplings! They were delicious! (Coming back soon to try their Xian cold noodles, which is the house favorite).
author: Linda L.

description:
I am coming to this place almost 2-3 times a week. Fell in love with their Mongolian beef, and had the best Xinjiang Chicken with noodle, and Xinjiang chicken in California. 
They still can work a little bit on their kababs)
author: Hajy A.

description: Yum! My friend, a SF native, took me here. I tried the veggie dumplings, chive pancakes, and enoki mushroom salad, and my friend had a beef chow fun. Everything was delicious. I especially want to commend the cold appetizer options at this place-very authentic Northern Chinese, and plentiful options. The enoki mushroom salad was vinegary, mixed with cucumbers, and so refreshing. I also had a hot soymilk which was yummy, but I sadly noticed that it's not made on premise, they just pour it out of a gallon. Was a tad bit pricey as I'm used to eating Chinese food in New York, where you don't spend $20 a person when you go out for just some dumplings and noodles as I had to here.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
This restaurant has very good noodles with reasonable prices and I really want to come again, but I doubt their health standard is up to the scale. When I visited, I didn't see the health rating hanging in front of the door. 

During the visit, I noticed a few things. The server grabbed raw food from the fridge and used the same hand to serve dishes to customers. We were sitting right next to the kitchen. There was a bucket of potatoes sitting on the floor. A lot of food preparations were done right outside of the bathroom. The table was very sticky and dirty. For food safety issues, I don't recommend you to bring kids eating here.
author: J L.

description:
Wifey and I are suckers for hand-pulled noodles.
They're like old-school an' stuff...

Eating old-school Chinese stuff reminds us that we're Chinese.
Gotta pay homage to the motherland, huh?

Anyway, order anything with noodles here.  Good.
Pan-fried buns here are tasty as well.

But ya wanna know a secret?
Promise you won't tell?
Get closer.

Closer...

Order the Xinjiang style chicken with noodles.

The most expensive thing on the menu at twenty bucks.
The order is big enough to feed 4, but is well worth it.
Chewy noodles, lean chicken, hearty sauce, and enough Sichuan peppers to numb your britches for a week!!

That's what China's about, beeyotch!

Word.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description: Pork elbow is good, beef tendon is on point, all the appetizers are pretty on point. The soup noodles are huge and the pork chive dumplings are tasty and full of juicy flavor. Have been coming here for dinner multiple times and it has always been a tasty satisfying dinner. Service language choice is basically chinese or mandarin but if you point on the menu and are open minded, service is super easy and pretty quick.
author: Thomas L.

description: I really wish I could give a negative score. I've waited for 1 hour for a bowl of spicy beef noodles!!!! Many people were getting their dumplings. I'm positive that noodles take much faster to boil than dumplings! I've asked several times for my order, I just got fed up and left. I literally just made a yelp because how frustrated I am with the wait staff particularly the female waitress!!
author: L W.

description:
This is an update a/o 10-17-15
I was craving pot stickers today and went solo to get some along with some green onion pancake. I remembered them to both be good. 
The pancake was thin and greasy, lacking taste. The filling of the potsticker seemed "loose" and not so good. The green onion pancake I buy from the frozen section of the Asian Markets are 1000x better theirs. 

While I was eating, I noticed that one of the cooks was tasting the broth of something a customer ordered with the utensil he was cooking with. It went back into the wok and he used this same tool to finish off the dish and scoop it for the customer. eeewwwllll

I won't be back for multiple obvious reasons!
author: May G.

description:
SLUUUURRRRRPPPPPPPPPP

It's a bit off putting when the first moment you enter into a restaurant and you see their staff members slurping on a bunch of noodles during their lunch break. This wasn't your typical noise of chattering and clinkering of plates but just multiple splurping noises coming in at different times. Luckily, there were plenty of seats around to be seated at that time. After standing around awkwardly for a couple of minutes, thinking that someone would come by to offer a table, I walked up to the front counter and asked to be seated. 

Shandong is your typical hole in the wall chinese restaurant with servers that only care about just getting the food to your table and nothing else. The only reason why you would come back to the place is because of their food and how affordable it is.

And that's pretty much what deems this place as good. The hand pulled noodles are whats so amazing about this place. It's freshly made, has a great al-dente texture to chew and of course...it's easily slurp-able. After initially judging others for being so loud in eating their food, i found myself joining in on the slurping noises! I really like their pork and chives dumplings and find them almost to the standard of Kingdom of Dumpling's

One thing to note is that it is CASH ONLY. There are plenty of banks/atms available though so finding cash shouldn't be too hard.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
My mom flew in from shanghai, and amazed by how authentic the dumpling and the rest of the dish were. My grandparents are from Shandong, so We are familiar with cuisine very well. 
The owners woke up around 3-4am every morning to prepare for all the dough, making from scratch. You can easily tell all the dumplings are well handmade.  
Flavors are awesome with great price tag!!! 
I love this restaurant, it's nice and cozy, and has free wifi!! 

Highly recommended.
author: Fanny Z.

description: The best Shanghai Dumplings (小笼包) I have had in San Francisco, hands down. All of their dumplings and noodles are handmade fresh, not frozen.  This place is great and is about as authentic of a Chinese food restaurant you can find outside China!  Their homemade spicy sauce is delicious. Great selection of dishes from different regions of China (Xinjiang, Hunan, Sichuan, Yunnan, etc.)
author: Andy B.

description:
It's a higher than average Chinese restaurant.  

I liked their black bean noodles, but part of me wishes the portion was larger.  

Also ordered their beef roll.  It's def a must order.
author: Joshua P.

description: Don't come here! It is so bad. We ordered two dishes: beef pancake and black bean pork noodles. Beef pancakes look like they are made two days ago and reheated at least twice, which is gross. And they are saturated with oil, literally dripping from the pancake. And the black bean noodles is not even black bean noodle! It Is a weird dish with green beans and tofu in it! Trust me I lived in Beijing for 4 years, I know what a black bean noodle should look like...
author: Matthew L.

description:
Looking for authentic Chinese food? This is the spot, and the best spot on Taraval. My regular is Dan Dan mian (spicy noodle soup) and guo tie (a larger sized dumpling). It's all very cheap, and the portions can feed two, but expect a small line at night. It's worth the wait. 

It's a great spot for a large group. I believe we reserved for 15 people once and they made it happen. If you are going on a date, it's also a good place, but it's not so quiet if that's what you are looking for, but still a good place for conversation. 

Enjoy!
author: Stevie G.

description:
Noticed this place on Taraval tonight, so my friend and I decided to try it. And,, it turned out to be a pretty nice restaurant.

Although there was only one waitress serving, the service was still good. She was quite attentive! In addition to the service, the dumplings were also a highlight of my meal tonight. They were fresh and not dry at all. They were full of fillings that treated delicious. Besides the dumplings, their hand made noodles were awesome! Try to get the soup ones though :p. The portions were huge! One plate of Xin Jiang noodles could be enough for two people for under $8 (before tax)!! However, I didn't find this plate to be extremely impressive except that the noodles itself was good. I will be back again though :).
author: Pui L.

description:
Food is nasty as their service. How can a waitress pick nose in front of customers?! Ew......We saw her picking her nose while we were asking for the check. Again, she was walking to us with the check and picking her nose in front of us!!! 
Besides the nasty service, their food is bad too. Don't order the smoked fish! It's very dry and without sauce. It's different than the one we normally have at somewhere else. It's the worst smoked fish I've ever had. Nasty!
DO NOT go to this place!
author: Chalina C.

description:
I'm so disappointed..
After checking the reviews here, I figured it was worth trying -after all, I live a block away from the place.

I ordered 2 pancakes. Twenty-five minutes and several other pick-ups later, I'm told that my order might not have been in after all. He proceeds to try to retake it. Uh No. I let him know I'm leaving and he assures me is coming in five minutes. Fifteen minutes later, I get my order. A total wait of 40 minutes for 2 orders of pancakes.
