The beef pancake tasted like they had dumped a cup of salt right on it, completely inedible. The onion pancakes are paper thin and super greasy... In fact they both were.

Definitely not worth the wait or the money.
author: Miss E.

description:
I can see why there are low ratings. I was sitting in the way back and saw them getting all the dumplings for each order out of a large freezer. Many were very seriously frozen together and had to be beaten apart. If you're in the front of the restaurant and wonder what that thumping is that you hear fairly regularly, now you know.

I didn't see all that when i initially placed my order for dumplings and noodles.

Nevertheless, despite this glaring warning, I was curious because of the (now clearly suspicious) positive reviews. The dumplings were horrible. They were pretty much inedible. They had clearly been frozen and were not any where near fresh. They did not even LOOK decent. They did not even taste kinda good. Bleck. Horrible is being nice.

I asked the waitress for what they were famous for. I figured it must be something other than dumplings. She suggested the noodles and suggested one dish as the most popular. She said the sauce is the part that is the best and what to really look for.

Hmmmmm

Well the noodles were crazy oily, like many reviewers noted. Not only that, but there was hardly any sauce. I added a bit of the mustardy sauce they offer. After adding that, I'm fairly sure this is the "sauce". It totally tasted the same, or at least VERY similar to the original sauce... Just more of it. The noodles themselves seemed decent. but i wonder what's the real story about them considering the dumplings and sauce fiasco. Basically the noodle dish sucked.

I won't even go into the smell, and the feeling that oil is in the air. My guess is that the smell is from oil. Hmmm

At least I had fresh baked cookies that I had made myself at home.... Otherwise I would have had a really hungry night ahead.

:(

I feel bad writing such a scathing review. The waitress at least seemed nice. It's not her fault the food sucks. But it was just to terrible, I had to do what I could to warn others. Save yourself.
author: Zoe D.

description:
This is an easy win for me. 
Pancake: more please!
Hand pull noodle: one of the best hand pull noodles i've had in a long long time.
Seaweed salad: Chinese style, more like kelp.
Dumplings: corn and chive- both good. I think it's better than kingdom of dumpling these days. I love the owner of kod, but their quality has gone down. And they got the same hot sauce.

Staff was friendly, unlike other yelper said, they seems quick and clean. Lets hope it like that everytime I come back.
author: jasmin t.

description:
Fresh hand pulled noodles with bean paste and pork probably the best item we had, a close second was beef wrap pancake.... so good! The dumplings are fab. 
Topped off with watermelon juice to counter the amazing hot sauce on condiment tray.
Low prices.
author: Ena O.

description:
If there was a 0 star option then I would give them that instead. Although some or a few choices here are quite delicious, their customer service is indescribably HORRIBLE. Okay, my fault that there's so much people in line and waited for almost two hour to be seated. Then Ms.Waitress comes and tries to take my order without her notepad, then fails her attempt and gets her notepad and takes my order (lamb skewers, celery and pork dumplings, Shanghai dumplings, crab dumplings, and pan-fried meat buns). 

First dish of lamb skewers were fine. But the Shanghai dumplings are disappointing. The skin of the dumplings were made poorly, therefore once I clamped my chopsticks on them, it broke immediately. Yuck, thought you were dumpling masters. 

Finally after asking the waitresses twice why our order is taking OVER 30 MINUTES to get out, it finally came, yeah, the wrong order. Then we had to tell them it's the wrong order then the pan-fried meat buns finally came out. Sorry, let me introduce that again. The OIL DRENCHED meat buns came out. 

Then after TWENTY MINUTES, after TWO more asks to the two waitresses why the orders are taking so long, the "celery pork dumplings came". Uh, no. Just kidding, it's corn and chicken dumplings. So I was to my extent and told them that it's not what I ordered and asked for the check. Okay. She comes and shows me that she cancelled the two dumplings and it's thirty dollars for eating four skewers of lamb, four Shanghai dumplings, and four oily meat buns. I was like, "This is thirty? Are you sure?" Then she recalculated and it was actually 19.50. 

Overall--horrible. It was unpleasant seeing other tables who came after us with tables filled with food in less than twenty minutes. Afterwards, I got the takeout menu and recalculated the check. We were charged extra $2.50. Could've given that money to a homeless person or for the meter, y'know. Go to this restaurant if you want horrible customer service and get ripped off. Tips? Didn't give any. They didn't deserve any. Took my fifty cents back for my piggy bank.
author: Cherry N.

description:
I bumped into this place by accident. Had no idea it is northern Chinese cuisine and I've never had it before. Looking at the menu and the prices, I was a bit concerned - do these low prices mean that I am risking Salmonella?
 
The young guy who took my order was helpful. I ordered some noodles with Chicken and Veges and chicken dumplings. 

Food arrived pretty quickly, first the noodles and then dumplings. Portions are huge here. I had eaten a decent meal about 2-3 hours earlier so wasn't particularly hungry. But as I dug into the food, I kept going on and on. It was delicious and fresh. Not greasy. And since seating is around the kitchen area, you can see it is prepared hygienically. And, the coke I ordered to wash off grease (something I always do at Chinese restaurants) was totally unnecessary. 

Cheap, delicious, non-greasy, huge portions, hygienic and served by a friendly staff. What's the catch? I couldn't find one. This place is a hidden gem.
author: TwinPeaker J.

description:
The food there always makes me feel like I was home back in China. Their cold noodle and xinjiang chicken with potato and noodle are things I crave for from time to time. The cold noodle is a typical cold dish in China but I can't find it often here. People who didn't grow up with Chinese food may find it strange at first. But this place is the number one restaurant for my Chinese friends and I. We all have our own favorites but we all LOVE the two I just mentioned. 

The only thing is it's a bit small inside and can be quite crowded. There's usually a line outside too. Well, if you see a Chinese restaurant that's super clean and empty, it's probably not real Chinese food anyway. Plus, you can just order takeouts.
author: Ironchef C.

description:
Ordered a chow mein that was drenched in oil. 
ordered an soup based mein and the soup had lots of oil too.
Way too much oil in the dishes.
author: Maybo T.

description:
This place is pretty small, but very clean and comfortable! Not a good place for a party more than 4. Very affordable and filling!


My friends and I ordered 3 dishes...

Xinjiang noodles with chicken: nothing special, but their noodles are very soft and chewy. They have green peppers in there. I ate one thinking it was a bell pepper, but it was so spicy!!

Jellyfish salad: too salty and sour. The jellyfish was good tho. 

Chicken and chive dumplings: the dough was chewy and the filling was good! Wish they had more juice inside it tho.
author: Josie D.

description:
The dumplings are standard - just like at any other place on Taraval.

The hand-pull noodles in soup are fine.

I do like the onion pancake here.

The Beef Roll Pancake is better at House of Pancakes.

The Spicy Pork Noodle is super spicy; they warn you about it. I had to dilute it with hot water, but even then there's some chili that is just extra spicy.

Overall, there are better options on Taraval. I wouldn't bother going here if I had to wait (which is common b/c the place is small and they get a decent amount of business). I would come again but recommend other places on Taraval to friends.
author: Derek M.

description:
Customer service ain't the best, but their food sure is good as long as you know what to get. Their tomato and egg noodles are good, and so are the rest of their other noodle soup choices. Their polished pancake dessert is killer, got to try it.

Sadly it's a little cramp inside, so I always order take-out from here. If I was ever in a pinch about what to eat, I'd call up this place
author: Tiff C.

description: This is a negative 5 star review. My best friend and I are not Chinese, but we live in the neighborhood and  expect to be treated courteously. They at least wiped down the high chairs for our sons, but that was it. We had to ask for a menu 3 times and every time I told the server (chunky Chinese girl with glasses) that we were ready, she just nodded and walked away... Helping other guests and ignoring us. I'm tired of that. Wake up people. We have money to spend and want to spend it... Don't forget about customer service
author: Antoinette C.

description:
Not sure why this place only has 3 stars.  It's delicious, and so cheap!  We had absolutely no problem speaking English - there were 2 completely fluent English speakers working there at 5pm on a weekday.

The tofu with preserved egg was delightful, but the star was certainly the Xinjiang chicken with knife-cut noodles.  Onion pancake was delicious too - thin and just a bit crispy, and it went well with their house made spicy sauce!!
author: Jon E.

description: I was meeting a friend for lunch in the Taraval area and we decided to go to Shandong Deluxe because House of Pancakes was too crowded. My friend ordered the beef chow fun, but I wanted something vegetarian today so I ordered the vegetable dumplings. I was disappointed with it. The dumpling had shredded cabbage, crystal noodles, and what looked like it could have sesame seeds. It didn't have any flavor and the vegetables had the texture of grounded meat. I liked that they gave a lot of dumplings so it was worth the money. But I wouldn't order the vegetable dumplings again. My friend's chow fun dish looked good and there were other people who ordered noodles that looked delicious too. I might return to try those dishes.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Hand pulled noodles are not bad. We usually go for the zha jiang mian. It's nice and chewy, but it's an occasional hit or miss with the flavoring. Their dumplings are yummy!!! especially the one with chives and shrimp. If you like it, you can also ask to buy frozen ones and boil them whenever you're craving them at home if it's a further drive for you. 

Unless you like a lamb-like tasting beef pancake.. I would not get that one. I'm not sure what it's called exactly, but it's one of the two pancakes that's advertised in their window. They say that the lamb-like tasting flavor might come from all the different herbs and spices they use... but who knows, I did not like it at all. 

Be careful not to mix up the vinegar and the soy sauce bottles.. They tend to be identical and both are not always provided on the tables. Their hot sauce is really good, but be very careful because it's pretty spicy! I usually use that on all my food =P. 

It's a hit or miss on the wait times.. sometimes they're ridiculously busy and other times they have no lines at all. From what I've observed, their longest lines are usually during lunch... especially on the weekends. Highly recommend getting there before 12 if you want to barely skip their rush hour! I could be wrong, but I also believe it is cash only. So make sure there's some Jacksons in your wallet.
author: Johanna T.

description:
Good food, bad service. 

It was night and day coming here the two times that I've been. The first was a weekday afternoon with NO ONE. The second was a PACKED weekend. So I would recommend coming on a slow weekday (if you have the time). 

All and all food was great. I loved the hand crafted noodles and flavorful broth. I don't exactly remember what I ordered, but you can't go wrong with any of the noodle soup dishes. Though I have been warned that there are apparently two chefs that make the noodles and one of them don't cut the noodles. So be prepared to eat a ridiculously long strand of noodle. You can request for a pair of scissors, but I don't recommend it because they were kids paper scissors (how unsanitary). The best bet is to ask them to cut the noodles prior when you're ordering.  

On to the bad service, when I did come back that second time I wasn't expecting such a long line. Taking into consideration that it was a weekend, our group didn't mind waiting for a little bit. But the wait got ridiculous, because the owner/server kept on letting people he knew cut us in line for about 30-45 minutes. I can understand that you would let people you know in first as a courtesy but after awhile it was just unfair to the rest of the patrons. After that our table was largely ignored because none of us spoke mandarin Chinese, so of course getting service was difficult. And when we were finally serviced (kind of) they were a little short/blunt with us. 

I would have given this place more stars if it wasn't for the service. Eaters beware!
author: Amy C.

description:
I only come here for one thing and one thing only: the pork and chive dumplings. 

I've been in love with them ever since the first bite after my roomie introduced me to this place since it's so close to Grandma's Saloon where we have our league nights for pool on occasion. It's so delicious and surprisingly not oily at all! Very well made and super cheap (12 dumpling for $6.99).

Only reason why I docked a star is cause I never eat inside of the restaurant itself which is semi cramped with only a dozen tables or so available and also because I've ONLY tried the dumplings, nothing else. I docked another star cause I usually only order pick up which is a feat all on its own because they sometimes have a difficult time understanding English so it takes me longer than I'd like just to place a pick up order over the phone. Other than that, it's worth the struggle. I find myself finding every excuse I can, if I seem to be passing by Taraval, just to make a quick pit stop for those damn dumplings.
author: Alexis A.

description:
I'm glad I have Chinese friends who explore restaurants and bring me to their favorites. The food here was great. Tried an assortment of pork and shrimp dumplings, pork pot stickers, beef pancake, and noodles (hello carbs!). All were delicious, but the spicy beef noodle soup was my favorite. It definitely has a good kick to it, and the noodles were chewy and fresh. I wasn't a big fan of the pork and fungus noodle, as I thought it was too earthy and bland. The beef pancake was crispy and fried and amazing, though I'd weigh a lot if I ate that every day. Dumplings and pot stickers were quite large, and stuffed full with meats and vegetables.

Service was just fine, once we were seated. It did take them a long time to turn over tables, which is too bad when you have 15+ people waiting outside. I recommend being persistent and checking up on the list--I think a group or two who came later were seated before us, just because they were hovering around the hostess stand. Not a lot of room to wait inside, so bring a jacket just in case you have to wait outside. Looking forward to going back!
author: Alison S.

description: I ordered dumpling and noodle to go, it just spent me more than 30mins, the most important thing is nobody was inside the restaurant, so I just don't know why they just looked like didn't want to cook my food. So bad experience, it made me not come here again.
author: Chan Kuei C.

description:
I came at around 5. It's 6:10 right now. Still waiting. They haven't even started cooking my dish. 

Will not be returning. Any place that takes more than half an hour to make freaking ramen is a no-go for me, hand made noodles or not.
author: Stacey D.

description:
Several new restaurants have opened along Taraval Street, this is one of them. Long story short, I definitely had better with better service. Since it is a new restaurant and it is sort of small, it is often packed with people. However, the table turn over rate is terrible (probably due to the lack of staffing), they will leave tables uncleaned for at least 10 - 15 minutes (at least when I was there). 

Wait list, forget about that! They did not follow it whatsoever! On the day I went, my family and I waited over 30 minutes, we were pretty much next for a table of 3. Somehow, after  they cleaned the tables, instead of going through the list, they asked people "how many people are in your party?" And then proceed to seat people. The family they seated first, arrived well-after we did. SERIOUSLY?!? Oh hell no! Luckily, I was standing inside the restaurant and demanded we be seated since we were next on the list. Originally, they offered us 3, one of those tiny table for 2 people. I said, no and requested a the four people table that was open. After we sat down, it took at least 10 minutes before we received a menu or water. 

Food-wise: It was blah for me. I have traveled to China and Taiwan before and had hand-pulled noodles. It definitely cannot compare, but compared to U.S. standards, it is quite crappy.  We ordered the Liang Pi (a cold noodle dish popular in Northern China and specially in the city of Xi'an, it is very refreshing to eat on a hot day!), dumplings, scallion pancake, one hand-pulled stir-fry noodle with lamb, and one hand pulled noodle beef broth bowl.

The Liang Pi was a let down. The noodles were horrible and the flavors just did not mix well, it was very oily. For a dish like Liang Pi, the noodles itself is very important. As for the dumplings, the skins was slight tough and the pork filling tasted funny (not in a expired way, but flavor-wise). Also, the stir-fry noodles with lamb, the flavors are interesting, its main base is a tomato sauce. The only two dish that I thought were decent was the scallion pancake and the beef noodle soup, you cannot screw up on the basics!

Food: 1.5/2
Service: 0/5
author: Wing Yan S.

description:
I'll admit the noodles were good, very chewy and unique. However, Shandong Deluxe made so many missteps my family will never go back. 

Service was meh, we got cold tea and none of the waiters wanted to look at us when we tried to flag them down for extra bowls. The decor was confusingly Japanese for a Shandong province restaurant, and fans were constantly running so everybody in the restaurant was sitting around in their North Face jackets. The smell of the restaurant was just bad, as if we were sitting next to a bathroom or fish tank. The table top was visibly dirty, and the teapot was broken but repaired with a mind-bogglingly ghetto/ingenious rubber band and toothpick contraption. 

Xinjiang noodles with beef: The flavor was ok, but the sauce didn't adhere to the noodles well. The vegetables in the dish were a very random assortment. It's like they were trying to make a pizza and dumped button mushrooms, tomato sauce, garlic, and bell peppers together before realizing they were running a noodle house. The bell peppers and tomato were cut up in a way that made the dish not cohesive with the celery or beef.

Beef stew soup noodles: Tender beef, meager vegetables, plentiful noodles, and SALLLLTY. 

Noodles with spinach dumplings: Good dumplings, bland everything else. 

My parents and I all wrestled with the noodles' length, which were a good two feet long. You cannot slurp a noodle of that length. You must pull it gamely into your mouth, inch by inch, like a snake eating another snake. We grew increasingly exasperated as our meal extended into dozens of meters, each bite turning to rubber between our tired jaws. We tried to order some rice pancake dessert, but the waiter said the wait would be half an hour, so we left. My mom tried to be optimistic and said we could get the pancakes next time, but everyone knew there will never be a next time.
author: Skye L.

description:
These people have no ethic and moral to be in the restaurant business. I'm fine with a restaurant that doesn't offer any good customer service. I'm also OK with dishes that aren't in the best of the world but  

DON"T LIE IN FRONT OF MY FACE SAYING THAT THERE'S CHICKEN IN THE FRIED RICE WHEN I SEE NO CHICKEN ! 

Here the story goes...

I requested a refund because we waited TOO LONG for it! They even want us to leave and let other customers to take the table. We were fine too and  waited another 15minutes outside. I went back in to cancel the order as soon as I know that they haven't start cooking it yet. 

THEY DO NOT WANT TO REFUND and insisted to wait for few minutes.... 

WOO HOO.... chicken fried rice is ready! 

I asked them, WHERE IS THE CHICKEN? I DON'T SEE ANY CHICKEN??!!!! THEY SAID CHICKEN IS INSIDE! 

BULLSHIT! 

That's how I got my refund back! This restaurant doesn't deserve any stars. 

(SHOUT OUT) This is America not China. Don't you ever use your dirty tricks to cheat people. You are making the rest of the chinese world look bad!

Food wasn't great at all. It's just the hype of "free styling noodle in the air" with their photos on it. Other dumpling & noodle places are better than them.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I write reviews either when something is right or horribly wrong, this place was just barely horribly wrong. 

Food was meh, I liked the dumplings, the skin was nice and el dente, xin jiang was mediocre and the intestines were oddly soggy. 

Plates, cups, chopsticks were all dirty..  Had to give the another wipe down, tea water was lukewarm and didn't even brew the tea bags. 

This place needs a lot of improvement.  But not a bad option if you are craving for some dumplings and hand pulled noodles. 

IMHO, Yolo somewhere else if there are alternatives.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Food: I ordered the beef tendon noodle and was pressured into getting the dumplings. 3 Stars.
Service: A big WTF. -1 Star

The food is okay; adding that spicy chili sauce they had definitely made it better. It is also a large portion. For the dumplings, I definitely had better. It is nothing special. 

Service-wise, the staff made me super uncomfortable. Just entering, the auntie that works there seat us down, gave us 2 orders of dumplings, told us it was still fresh they just made it, and told us to eat it. I was confused and absolutely clueless at what's going on at that moment. I kept asking the auntie how much was it. She did not answer. She told a younger female server to come to speak to us. My friend and I kept asking how much are the dumplings, she did not answer. We ask if it's on the house or they're doing a promotion deal because we were the last customers of the night...After a 5 minute exchange about the dumplings, she finally said it was not and took out the menu and told us the price. Afterward, she said they are willing to do buy one get one 50% off. Feeling forced, the auntie was staring us down, we took the deal. We just wanted to order the noodles, but it looked as if she didn't even want to show us the menu and basically just told us what to order.
author: Chelsea C.

description: We didn't actually see anyone pulling noodles, but the kitchen was out of sight.  These are DEFINITELY hand pulled noodles, something very hard to find in SF.  We had the "spicy" combo seafood and pork noodles (wasn't that spicy, but very tasty) and the pork, shrimp, and chive dumplings.  Good stuff.  Also tried the chive pancake - really good, huge portion.
author: Kevin L.

description: Another amazing restaurant named Shan dong in the sunset? Yes. Delicious hand pulled noodles in a yummy broth.
author: M-E C.

description:
Food is good, but service is horrible. Expect waiting very long (we waited over an hour tonight), grabbing your own menu, and along a least a dozen times for water (they didn't give us water when we were seated). 

Dumplings, hand pulled noodles, and the beef pancake are the only reasons to come here.

If you want better food and great service, don't waste you're time coming here. Just go to Shanghai dumpling house on Balboa.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
My mom's dad was originally from this province of China before they immigrated to Taiwan so she knows a thing or two about this type of food.  We ordered XLB and I think this was one of the soupiest dumplings I've ever had!  We also got that spicy noodle dish, I forget what it was called.  Most of the other tables also got this noodle soup dish and I loved the hand pulled noodles but other than that I left most of it for my mom and dad.  The green onion pancake was delicious although a little oily.  The chive stuffed pancake was also good but it was chive overkill for me.  We also got an order of shrimp fried rice for my boyfriend which he polished off fairly quickly, (so much for leftovers).  We also got the shrimp, pork dumplings which were also very good.  

Everything we ordered was good but there were a bunch of things not available on the menu.  I wanted to order the beef chow fun to take home, no, they didn't have it, then the rice cake, no to that too.  So rice it was.  

They gave an honest effort with the decor and it was nice compared to other hole in the wall chinese restaurants.  We will definitely be coming back.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Same as king of noodle. They took over the (recent) Doraku Ramen. Yay
For the noodles and Shanghai dumplings--hit or miss.. some days it's cooked perfectly...some days the noodles are overcooked and/or the dumplings aren't juicy.
author: Miss J.

description:
Our family loves this hole in the wall restaurant. The dumplings and noodles are delicious.  Have a glass of water handy if you're ordering the spicy beef noodle soup.  
Service is lacking, but the food makes up for it.
author: E C.

description:
They have really authentic dumplings that I've ever had in the San Francisco Bay Area. Even compared to some of the great dumpling places in China, they may still be able to get their spot on the top list. 
We only ordered beef dumplings, leek shrimp dumplings and Xinjiang chicken. I also ordered beef dumplings, leek pork dumplings and cabbage pork dumplings to go. Beef dumplings are by far my favorite. It's super juicy and has very rich flavor. 
As for the service, they only have two waiters/waitresses and it does take a long time from start to finish, and there is at least half an hour waiting time. I would usually give four stars in this case. But since the dumplings were so good and blew my mind, I would totally recommend this place!
author: Dorothy C.

description:
All of the northern Chinese specialities are excellent: hand pulled noodles 手拉麵，dumplings 水餃 and the cold noodles 涼皮.  Especially amazing was the discovery that they have Xi'an Cold Noodle Salad 
西安涼皮. This dish is tangy and luscious and has little bite-size morsels of gluten that perfectly absorb the vinegar and  sesame paste sauce.  

I lived in China for three years and I am pleased to go to a restaurant where I hear witty, fast spoken Mandarin. The customer service is quick and straight forward. They are able to accommodate one larger group table that is served giant portions of delicious smelling food. 

Every time I go I look at all the dishes to see what I will have next time I come. Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Jimi G.

description: This place makes great handmade noodles. We always get their chicken chow mein and scallion pancakes. The beef rolls are good too. We like the pork shrimp and chive dumplings. Great garlic hot sauce. We go here regularly.
author: Marica C.

description: We got the beef stew noodle soup. Sadly, they barely added any meat and the broth was tasteless. I had the mapo tofu here before and this time around it didn't have the pork and literally tasted like the jar of mapo tofu sauce from the grocery store (super sour). Pork and spinach dumplings were typical. Overall this dinner was a bummer.
author: Kob A.

description:
I was in the area and needed some food TO-GO... (Giving 2 stars because they were willing to take my TO-GO order.) I actually made it 5 mins before closing. It was a packed house...There were still a ton of patrons. The barely English-speaking waitress told me that the kitchen was closing and needed me to order immediately. She didn't bother hiding the fact that she was irritated and rudely rushed me to order. Being my first time there, I asked her to suggest a noodle dish. She recommended the Xinjiang Noodles. So I took her recommendation and also ordered the shrimp with chives dumpling, green onion pancake and mongolian beef. Spent $30 total. 

As I waited for about 10 mins, I watched the same waitress turn away a couple that wanted to eat there. Astonishingly, I also watched two separate goups walk in that seated themselves. At the time, the waitress was in the back and didn't see the two groups walk in. However, I witnessed the whole thing unfold and saw her extremely pissed off reaction when she discovered what happened. She ended rushing them through their order as well.

Anyways, I got my food and went home right away to eat it. To my utter disappointment, everything was ridiculously nasty. With the exception of the shrimp dumplings that were tolerable. I am not a picky eater. But even with my asian palate, I couldn't bare eating the food. The food was just ridiculously flavorless. The worst dish was the Xinjiang Noodles!!! I couldn't believe it!! I even tried reviving it with some soy sauce and hot sauce but it was so far gone that it was beyond edible. The mongolian beef was practically just as bad. And the green onion pancakes were nothing to rave about. Not even sure if they deserve 2 stars and $30 bucks..... Bad service plus bad food should equal to zero stars. Not going there again.
author: Mary L.

description:
Cold, long wait, on a Friday evening. Small restaurant and line doesnt move very fast. Overall food was good, we tried about 6 different things. Highlights were the pork dumplings, potstickers, the beef roll, and the spicy beef noodles.

We didnt love the hot and sour soup.

The prices are insanely good.

I'd go back

We thought the service was attentive and quick, not sure why all the bad reviews on service surround this place.
author: Michael B.

description:
An extra star for the hand pulled noodles alone.  My relatives and I really wanted to try this place out for lunch today. We got seated right away and we ordered one beef stew noodle bowl and one beef tendon noodle bowl.  Both arrived promptly and in fairly good sized bowls. The broth was well made, not overly salted with additives. The hand pulled noodles were soft and chewy. I loved it! Warning, the noodles were crazy long, so be prepared to ask for scissors or a knife to cut them. My beef tendon were soft and succulent, just this side of gelatinous heaven. It came with Chinese mustard greens for color and balance.

We also ordered the xiao long bao, which has the juicy broth I expected, but not the ginger flavor in the pork meat which I didn't expect. I'm not a fan of ginger so I was taunted by the little morsels...didn't help that I had 3 baskets of xlb at Shanghai Dumpling King the night before...xlb overload!

I wouldn't recommend the beef pancake, mom assumed they would be pan grilled, not completely fried up into a greasy brown hot mess. The meat filling was good but the over fried dough was a total turn off.

Service was brisk and the parking was pretty good in the afternoon.

Cash only!
author: Pauline L.

description:
I wish I could give no star. Words cannot explain how disappointed I am right now. 

- the WORST food ever(noodle? What a joke. They will serve you some flavored shoelaces.) 
- no consideration for the customer 

Please don't go. Just, please.
author: Wakako K.

description: Had the preserved vegetable pork noodles, dumplings, 生煎包, sesame sauce cold noodles. Overall the dishes taste very authentic and tasty. If it's just food I would've given 5 stars. We didn't have the best dinning experience as tea cups were dirty and the service was the greatest. I would definitely come back again on a weekday.
author: Da D.

description:
Been coming here the past few weeks with classmates during lunch break.  

Typically we have about 4-5 people which allows us to order a variety of dishes.  

Everything from appetizers to dumplings to large massive chicken.  

Their opening dishes are pretty good and are probably the best out of the bunch.  I really recommend the cold cucumbers in garlic and hot oil beef and tendon.  

The dumplings are aiight, not too much better than store bought frozen ones from 99 ranch.  

We also often order the stir fry noodles and other noodles but it's pretty standard faire and nothing to write home about. 

All in all though, this place offers genuine China Chinese dishes at a standard price point.  Not many of these kinds of places around but more and more are popping up, competing with the existing cantonese style Chinese restaurants.
author: Dennis C.

description:
Nice interior design.  Ordered E3 because the waitress said it was there most popular dish (celery, tomato and some spicy sauce).  The hand pulled noodles was pretty good.

 Cash only
author: Jboogie L.

description: I come here so often, very good servers and very Delicious dumblings ! Shangdone dumblings are so famous in China as well!
author: Charles K.

description:
Ramen House changed into Dumpling House. Same decor (even with the ramen plaques) but better food. Small place so you can see the fresh dumplings being made in the back area of the hallway. I was mildly surprise at how much I liked their noodles. I have been going back for a quick meal of warm noodle soup and hot dumplings.

* Spicy Beef Noodle (4 of 5) $6.95 - Flavorful and filling. I think this is my favorite spicy beef noodle in the Sunset Area. I would like more beef, but they give so much noodle. The spiciness it not too hot, but not too mellow. And not to sour, as some places serve it. It has a great amount of noodle and I really like the noodle choice. It is chewy, stringy, and fresh tasting. 
* Pork and Chive Dumplings (12) (4 of 5) $5.95 - Fresh and tasty. I have no complaints. The freshly cooked dumplings are tasty. Best to eat it as soon as it gets to the table.  
* Black Bean Noodle (2.5 of 5 ) $6.95 - It is a pass for me. They use the same noodle as the soup one, but their sauce base is dry and not that tasty. Their black bean sauce does not compliment the noodle or coat it to be a good tossing noodle choice. Too bad. I was really hoping this was another hit. But it is a pass for me. I will keep with the noodle in soup.

Been going back often when I want some hot noodle soup to warm up from the cold and wet winter. I don't recommend for large groups since it is a super small place. Good for 1-4 eaters. Cash only.
author: Janice T.

description: Really authentic northern Chinese cuisines! Like the homemade place. Feels like sitting in the dining room in my home with family!
author: Savi M.

description:
Excellent lamb noodle dish.  The meat was tender and the noodles were chewy.  This time the noodles were easier to cut using the spoon, since the noodles are so long that it is hard to put in a small bowl for sharing.  Chive dumplings was also good and tasty. 

Service wise you have to actively ask for the check, boxes, small bowls for sharing, and to order.  I guess you don't expect the greatest service here, but I thought they could definitely improve on taking initiative to engage their customers.
author: Ben S.

description:
Here is my experience. We were two people and ordered two dishes. One is a simple Chinese dish (need maybe 5 mins to cook)  and other is Xianjing style chicken.( all the problems from this dish)
When we been there just six customers at there and they separated each different tables. I thought our two dishes would be on the table fast but the fact was a joke. Wait about 1 hour just for that Xianjing style chicken so I just let their staff know( yeah..it was staff..cuz their waiters were disappear. ) Finally, I run out my patience and also, I found their waiter which is a Chinese boy. I asked how long should I wait a chicken usually, and he said,"30 mins at least". OK, fine, so why didn't you tell me when I order this? he said" I thought you guys already know that". Oh~~~ this is my first time been there and why should I know before? Also, it was your think..SO..WHO ARE YOU? A SEER?
BTW, their food just so-so. Trust me, cuz I am came from northern China if your geography was get an A, B or C you will be know what I am talking about. 
Do NOT waste your time and money put their poor little business in. Their food or customer service beneath each Chinese restaurant around SF and Bay Area.
author: Young L.

description: Yes yes yes!! Yum this is amazing food I love it when I'm hungry I can war up to 5 dumplings
author: Archit B.

description: good food, but really bad service. make mistake all the time, give us wrong order, cancel our order when the chef argued with the restaurant keeper.
author: Paine W.

description:
Oh grandma in back making the dumplings how i love seeing you there and grandpa in the kitchen cooking... the patriarch and matriarch of the family hold this place down...
"Yes the xiao lum bao are good... , the hand made noodles... the cold salads of black funger, cucumber, or bean thread in a light sesame dressing..
it's experiencing a incredible popularity thing so be patient... the staff is nice and trying their best... and well... i love it...
I have eaten here thirty times in the past couple monthes i'd say and i'm not growing tired of it... although their cousins are running the shanghai pancake house up the street and it's great too!... it's funny their items don't really take away from the other.
Great people Great food Great times...
author: Adam O.

description:
I always come here when I don't know where or what to eat. Yes, it's a small restaurant so the wait could be long sometimes. And parking could be difficult especially around lunch or dinner. But this place has the best northern style Chinese food in town and I have tried everything on the menu.
I always have the fish dumplings and their noodles. All the noodles are hand made and taste just like the one I had in China. I also like the beef pancake. It's so juicy and flavorful. If you come here with a group of four or more, the xinjiang style chicken with noodle would be a good choice. It comes with potatoes, green peppers, dried chili, and of course, chicken and noodles. The noodle is different from other dishes. It's flatter and chewier and larger. Two of those noodles and some dumplings would be more than enough for me. But if you like foods with strong flavor, you should definitely try this one. 
I would recommend anyone who wants to try authentic northern style Chinese food to this place.
author: F. Z.

description:
It's great to have this restaurant open up on Taraval Street   I'm told that the chef here is from the Shan Dong Restaurant on Geary between Arguello and 2nd Ave. Also the menu looks similar to that from the House of Noodles on Irving near 18th Ave (and I also recognize one of the staff as being from there). It's the same good noodles and decent dumplings.

This place may got pretty busy now because it's fairly new. As a result, they're service can be slow after ordering. Hopefully they work out this kink.
author: H K.

description:
I wouldn't recommend coming here with a big group. This place was tiny and even some of the two-person tables were cramped. We had to wait a while before my group of nine was fully accommodated. They let us combine two big tables together but we had to wait about 40 minutes for that to be available.

I ordered the zha jiang mian. The noodles and sauce were good, and the tofu was okay. It didn't really have a lot of meat though. Other people at my table who ordered the same thing felt it could've used more pork too. Serving size was decent considering the price. We also ordered xiao long bao for the table. This place obviously isn't a place which specializes in it so I didn't expect much. They were pretty average, mostly because the skin was a lot thicker than what I'm used to.

The service overall is pretty friendly, especially considering that our group was large and most people in our group weren't Chinese. The waitress seemed to have trouble speaking English and would constantly speak Chinese to me and one other person to translate her words to everyone else. She was able to take our orders in English but seemed confused when people would ask her questions. Not sure if anyone else had that experience but it might be something to be aware of.
author: Allen C.

description:
Wasn't sure what type of restaurant this was. 

Came in for some lunch with my family and we were seated in the corner table. Why do I mention this? Oh because the corner table couldn't have been more cramped! The seats at the table were so cushioned that when I sat down, I sank into the seat and felt that the table was very high and I had to put greater effort to bring my arms up and over the edge.

The food is so-so....typical greasy Chinese food. We ordered Mongolian beef, black bean noodles, the seafood stew and an order of Xiao Long Bao. I did not really enjoy anything here honestly.....I'm not saying the food was terrible, I just couldn't tolerate the grease here at all. What made it worse was the restaurant became somewhat smoggy after a few more tables filled up. It was very uncomfortable to be sitting in there, breathing in those fumes, while trying to consume what we could. 

Service is hard to get. I think it's primarily because we don't speak Mandarin, but it could also be because we were seated AT the corner table.

I don't think I will be coming back anytime soon.

C
author: Alex T.

description:
Was very skeptical about coming here. I'm glad I got it out of the way for lunch and not dinner. 

I got 4 things:
Chicken chow Marin
Black bean noodles
Chicken dumplings with napa cabbage
Tofu skin salad

I enjoyed the tofu skin salad a lot. It was very good! The rest of the dishes were unfortunately too salty. The dumplings too!! 

It's very weird that they don't include any serving utensils for their dishes. It's very much a struggle to get food on your plate. 

They have a hot sauce which is a rip off of kingdom of dumpling a few blocks down, except not as spicy. 

The service was good even for one server. 
It's new so they're working their kinks out. 

I give them 2 stars for the tofu salad and the server. 

I'd probably won't be back anytime soon.
author: J V.

description:
Omg! Their foods sooooo good! 
I ordered onion pancake, mutton stewed noodle and spicy beef tripe, btw this is my first time try beef tripe, taste is wonderful!
Service is good too!
author: K. J.

description:
Not bad.. I tried it on the recommendation of some old Chinese folk-friends of mine.

The noodles itself were fantastic. Chewy, freshly made, and overall quite good in the noodle department; you can see the cooks making the noodles behind the kitchen.

The spicy beef broth on the other hand was a bit oily and tangy for my liking. This may be more of a taste-issue on my part, so please take the review with a grain of salt.

I guess Chinese noodle soups and my taste buds aren't meant to be. I wasn't a big fan, so I just picked out pieces of bok choy and noodles and left the rest. (8$ lunch)

The service was good; rather sporadic but what do you expect for a cheap eats. Clean eating area... it seems to be a neighborhood spot for local Chinese peeps though.
author: Roy C.

description: Skip the xiao lung bao and go for the dumplings, so juicy and tasty.  Economically more bang for your buck.  Leftover dumplings are even juicier. Everything is made to order resulting a bit of a wait on food.  If you sit in the back, you might see them pulling the actual noodle.  The deluxe noodle dish cost $19.95, good for four people, fat flat noodles with supposedly the whole chicken with two feet.  Chili is swimming among the big square plate.  I prefer the stir fried noodles over the soup ones.  The black bean noodle was really good the last time with tiny little tofu on the bottom.  I loved the fried bao.  Try the garlic chili sauce next to the soy sauce and vinegar.  It adds a zing to your food.  Excuse the service, there's only two people running around.  Don't bring more than five people or else there is a long wait or you have to sit on top of each other.
author: Helen L.

description: Not sure why the reviews are so bad. I went in here today for the first time and I enjoyed it. I ordered the beef noodles, the potstickers and the cucumber salad. The noodles were chewy and homemade, the broth was light and the beef was tender. The potstickers were my favorite, very juicy, chewy dough with lots of meat. The cucumber salad was average, I have had better. The place is small but decent, I have been to smaller restaurants. The service was average, it is the typical chinese restaurant service so don't expect much. I will come back. And I will recommend this place.
author: Melissa C.

description: To be clear, I am not rating this restaurant based on how the food tastes. Mainly because I never got the chance to taste the it!! Sat down and was able to have my order placed within a couple minutes of deciding what I would like. Thought to myself, "the server is nice, and the service is pretty quick." Then it just went downhill from there. Waited half an hour and nothing had come out, so I inquired about our food. The server went to check after he finished up what he was already doing. That took about 10 minutes and came back to tell us that he have out order to another table. A little frustrated that they didn't notice we were sitting at a table with no food for so long, but it happened so nothing we could do about it. Now I'm expecting that they would at least rush to cook our food first since they made a mistake but nope. Sat an extra 20 mins and we said f... It.
author: Alfred W.

description:
It's a shame that I will probably stop eating here. Their food is pretty good but it was a nightmare picking up a Togo order. 

I waited 50 minutes to get my food after calling in ahead of time after work. I constantly checked to see if my food was ready and they were trying to ignore me.

Hopefully they can get service right here.
author: Tony L.

description:
I found my grandma's taste in this restaurant. Even though I am Cantonese, born and raise in Hong Kong. My mother side grandparents were originally from Shandong China. I was eating Shandong food more than 1/2 of my childhood. I guess I am familiar enough to talk about Shandong cuisine. I've read about the other comments compare noodles or dumplings from Beijing and Xi'an. It is hard to compare because Shandong and Xi'an or Beijing styles are very different . I highly recommended the pork and napa cabbage dumplings and Wan Tou ( 山東大饅頭 ) ( the big Shandong Bun) which is a real big shandong bun, nothing like the soft little buns you will find in dim sum place. I also like the Shandong bun with pork, napa cabbage and edemame beans inside which was recommended by the owner ( they lady making dumplings at the back) after I've had a nice conversation with her. I 've lost this taste since my grandma past away back in the 90s. I felt touching which brought me back a lot of good memories because of this pork bun. My grandma made this bun exactly the same way. 

I guess I created my fusion way to eat this plain big buns when I was in kindergarten and I would like to share with everyone. I used to cut this bun into pieces, toast it and put butter on it. Give it a try, taste very great even though it does not sound very healthy. 

I really want to give five stars but I took one star out because of one waitress. I am not sure which part of the world she's from? I ordered 7up, she looked very lost and asked me what was it. So I asked for Sprite and said it in Mandarin, she brought me a glass of ice water? I asked again for Sprite, she looked very lost and asked the other waiter to help me. The other waiter apologized to me and told me she was 3 months new to the country and not familiar with the names of sodas in the US.... Huh?? What can I say?  I've been to different parts of China since early 80s, that girl looks like she is in her 20+. I saw 7up and Sprite most of places in China. Plus,  I have to speak English, Cantonese and Mandarin in my job almost everyday, no one ever complain about my Mandarin even though it is not my first language. I am confident that my Mandarin is understandable due to my family background. I wonder if that girl was from China? Venus? or Mars? 

Other than that girl, I will give 5 stars. I like the lady owner a lot, she is very nice lady.
author: Katherine L.

description:
Restaurant: Cash Only, although there are several banks nearby

Service: Server took our orders late and ended up serving us food that was supposed to be for the table across the room.

Food: 
* Subpar compared to the other dumpling places around the area.  
* Pan-Fried dumplings looked delicious, but lacked in flavor.  
* Shanghai soup dumplings were a huge disappointment, as 4 out of 6 had bursted before it arrived in our table.  
* The chive/pork/shrimp dumpling as well as the pork/corn dumpling was okay, but couldn't really tell the difference in their recipe from Kingdom of Dumplings further down on Taraval close to the beach or King of Noodles on Irving. 
* Now that I think about it, even their hot sauce they served was shockingly similar, but the hot sauce here had intensely more garlic, and has more of a oily creamy texture.
* Their beef fried pancake was bland.

The food was fast, we got all of it within about 13 minutes or so, and the restaurant was pretty clean.  But to be honest, it was somewhat of a let down because there are already two really good dumpling places around that offers better food at similar price points.  

The Shanghai Soup Dumpling fiasco was the most disappointing of all.  If you can't get that right, please, for the love of humanity, don't plaster that dish as your house specialty on your window.

I haven't tried their noodles yet, so I can't review this, but right now I'm seriously questioning whether or not I should go back at all.  Perhaps it's about time to refocus the kitchen team back to bring back decent flavor in their food consistently.
author: J T.

description: Love the dumplings here! Tried a lot of times and different kinds! I often buy frozen ones in bulk after I had dinner there so I can make them at home.
author: Z L.

description: Food here is super delicious. Authentic Northern Chinese cuisine reminds me so much of Xi'an city in China.
author: Yining Y.

description: Been here a number of times as its closed to where I live right now. The northern chinese is pretty good! Try the hand pull noodle! And 羊肉膜！
author: Alanda B.

description: I almost don't want to leave a review for fear of it getting too popular but I love this place!
author: Jessica G.

description:
These people have a nasty attitude. My name was on the waiting list, but the idiot servers kept seating the people that's not on the list first. After 45 minutes of waiting I got fed up and went in to voice my concern. They told me I can leve if I don't like it. 

Why do we keep supporting these people that treat their customer like crap?
author: UR D.

description: Love the Xin jiang chicken（新疆大盤雞）. The best Chinese food restaurant in Bay area
author: Hx T.

description: Simply put, you are not here for the service, you're here for the food. Top notch dumplings, home made noodles, and pancakes. One of my favorite places!
author: Nelson S.

description: The food here is good...but not the service, me and my girlfriend went here to try their chicken dish, which cost $20 and we ordered other stuff. However they made us to wait for over 30 mins for the chicken dish, but the table behind me some how got the chicken dish before us even they came much later than us. During the time we wait, I tried to ask the one of the lady to check out our order, but all she said was I knew you had ordered one. "Nice" services.
author: Di W.

description: Service is bad. Half of the furniture are broken in some way, the table we were sitting at was rocking and the chairs were making a sound. There are only two kinds of noodles in this place, the thick and the regular. Ordered the wonton noodles and another friend ordered the Chow Mein, same noodles but prepared differently. Came back another day and wanted an order of the chow mein to go, they gave me chow fung. Portions are large depending on what one orders.
author: M C.

description: The portions are pretty big and so is the bill.  I guess I always thought Chinese food is cheap, but that is no longer true.  $45 for 3 dishes.  Food taste pretty good here.  But the quality of the meat is almost as bad as street food quality in China.  Noodles are done well.
author: Byron L.

description:
After looking at my good friend Cindy FB posting.   I've too decided to have dinner here over the weekend.  The food was OK,  but the restaurant COLD air intake/exhaust was miserable.  I've had to ask the waiter to bring me some hot water so I can warm my hands.  Shan Dong Deluxe Restaurant Fail :(
 Fix that fan of yours, or use your restaurant as a freezer.
author: Jeni F.

description:
Large portion and tasty food. 

Xin Jiang Noodle is a must order here. Hand pulled noodles with a choice of beef or lamb stir-fried with celeries, bell peppers, onions and tomatoes. Lamb is very tender and we love the taste of this dish.

Dumplings and Xiao Long Bao are just ok here. It's pretty standard and there's not much to write home about. 

The restaurant is new. Service can be a little slow, but the food comes out very fast after you place an order.
author: Saran R.

description:
We ordered to-go twice within a week as we liked it the first time. My husband is a picky eater when it comes to Chinese food. We love the handmade noodle and will certainly go back to them. It is however, a little on the salty side for us but again this is personal preference.
We did not dine in but the server answering the phone was nice and my husband said the waiter/waitress were very friendly too when he picked up. There was a nice older lady who even opened the door for him when he left.
author: Chung T.

description:
Came here for lunch on a slow Wednesday.

The waiter stick us in a corner with a table with space only enough for 2 bowls of soup, while the rest of the restaurant is completely empty save for 1 table.  The waiter looked like he's got better things to do elsewhere, if only the customers would be considerate enough to stay away.

They are supposed to serve Northern Chinese food so we ordered dumplings and hand pulled noodles among other items.  Let's just say, frozen dumplings from Kingdom of Dumpling and Korean instant noodles are pretty good options, too.

They have a whole range of stuff, if you're in the mood to try more 'adventurous' items.

Good luck!
author: daphne w.

description: The DApan Ji is good, but took long times.
author: Wei H.

description:
Love, love, love the soup here, the noodles are delicious and the dumplings are always moist.  
The service has always been fine when we've gone, they've even answered the questions my bf had about another table's dish on more then one occasion. 
This is my new go to Chinese food restaurant.
CASH ONLY.
author: Angie L.

description: I ordered the beef tendon noodles to go. Noodles were exactly the right consistency - chewy and al dente.  Soup was good, not greasy. The tendon was too smooth, soft and slippery for me. I like tendon cooked more thoroughly.
author: G C.

description: Xiao long bow is really good! It's freshly made, which takes longer to serve. Noodles are also freshly made in the semi open kitchen. Glad to see Santong style noodle and dumpling place on Taraval street. But, don't expect too much on the service. Cash only!
author: L K.

description:
Good dumplings.  Really bad noodles.


This was my second time here.

I ordered the Jajaing Mein: bean paste and pork noodle:
The noodles are hand made, but over cooked.  The sauce is watery, one dimensional--as if they gave up on draining the noodles and just slopped a ladle of canned bean sauce.  Instead of finely minced pork and tofu, there were sparse bits of dried tofu and token amounts of meat.  Instead of cucumber of green onions, there were leftover bits of veggies (raw green berms and a course lay chopped white onion.)

The dumplings were good.  Firm skin, hot, good filling.

The reason why 2 starts, not 3:

1. Service: the waitress recommended the most expensive items of each section with no consideration to others ordered.  She's also constantly in a rush for tips.

2. The noodles were *really* sad.  For a shandong restaurant, I'd expect decent noodles.  As it is, I could cook better than this as a 12 year old!

3. This is the Sunset district of SF.  Chinese cuisine is expected to be at a high standard.  This is more of what I'd expect in the boonies of Manatoba.
author: Matt L.

description:
Went there yesterday, after reading the article in the Chronicle.  A bit disappointed with the food and service.  Small place.  Seems to be family run.  Very disorganize and cleanliness is not so good.  We had to return the plates, cause bits of the previous diner's food was still on the plate.  The teacup was greasy.  

We ordered the cold cabbage salad.  I was expecting the typical "bai chai" with the vinegar and chili spices, but it was a bit different.  Taste was okay and the portion was acceptable.  Their spicy hand pulled noodles soup with seafood was good.  Better than most places.  

We ordered one of the pan fried pancakes with meat fillings.  The outer crust was burnt and inedible and the inside was not cook and the meat filling was a bit bland.  

They need to work on service and clean the tables a bit better after each group of diners.  

My final opinion, food is okay but they need a little more work before they are ready for prime time.

JMHO
author: brian l.

description: This will be the 3rd and last time I am going to eat here, the first time was okay, no complaint.  I had lunch here to day, I order some potstickers and some pan fried bao, the dough was so thick that we had to split them out, we also ordered some beef noodle soup, it was very very salty.  We nicely asked advised them of the salty soup, they added some hot water in there and made the soup then tasted like water, my entire family was not please with the food. I had much better food than this place, this place is really going down hill.  I do not recommend this place AT ALL!!!
author: Tiff K.

description:
Zero star. Worst service ever. Was only given one menu for six people. One of the servers asked us to order quickly. I told her very politely that my mom just went to the restroom and maybe we could start with whatever we had ordered and then add more. She then said, "You'd better hurry because you have occuppied the table for so long already." Lady, you want your customer to order from a restroom???
We were very upset and my father tried to complaint. She did not even listen but just apologized very loudly without sincerity and just wanted to embarrass us in front of other customers.
Food was horrible too. We ordered some vegetarian dumplings and pot stickers and there was only cabbage and LOTS of gingers inside. Hello, you are not here to fool native Chinese. 
Would not recommend at all. No more business for them,
author: carrie H.

description: Don't even bother to come here, the food wasn't great and the service was beyond horrible. They asked us to pay and leave but we haven't even received all of our food. The table next to us had their $100 bill from the bank rejected and they were extremely insulted. But I guess it just a hour and a half I'll never get back.
author: brandon y.

description:
The name and decor of the restaurant is catchy. There is a picture of the owners with Mayor Ed Lee.  You would expect a typical asian restaurant in sf, hot tea, quick service, soup and appetizer served first etc. The table was dirty.  The restaurant did not deliver.  The tea was cold so I asked for a replacement. It was cold. I got the green beans first, it was just drenched in soy sauce and cold. I got the hot and sour soup, it was thin.  The dumplings and bean curd were ok. Had better.
We also did not get sauce bowls either.  The service ruined the ambiance for a wonderful friday night. The staff should learn from other restaurants on Taraval about service. Maybe they never dined out at a restaurant.

First time in my life I had to leave a low tip.
author: Sharon C.

description: I would give this place a no stars if I could.  Consumers BEWARE!!!  I ordered the mushrooms but when it came it it had cucumbers in it.  I let them know I could not eat cucumbers and I didn't want the plate.  Initially I thought that was that, but instead they brought the plate back to me with the cumbers picked out of it.  I had thought they made a new dish for me and bit right into it.  I told the waitress I didn't want the dish and that I am pregnant and could not risk getting sick. She replied in Mandarin "what there is no cucumbers".  Then I pointed to the cucumber that i had picked out, and she pretended not to understand.  I replied fine.. I will never come back here again. Then she walked away.  I went on trying to enjoy the rest of my meal, until I heard her talking to another costumer in english..in fact helping him translate English to Mandarin.  After I heard that I was fuming with anger.  I cannot believe HOW LOW the restaurant will stoop to to make a few dollars, really the plate was 6-7$.  I can't imagine how may other corners they would cut to make a few bucks! Unethical would not trust
author: Maggie L.

description: The dumpling is very good, especially fish dumpling, it is so fresh and better than china. And another perfect food is chao ma noodle, a little bit spicy and very delicious!!
author: Dalu L.

description:
This used to be the old Ramen Doraku, which was always empty...one morning I was passing by on my way to work and noticed that a new sign had gone up over the old one. Since then I always saw at least a couple customers in there, and even more as the days went on.

We thought we'd take a chance and visit for the first time last night. The decor inside is pretty much unchanged, but bright and cheery. 

We ordered the pork and chive dumplings, spicy beef noodle soup, and pork with peppers. The overall bill (without tip) came to be about $21, which was pretty good considering the portions! The dumplings were tender, and very plump. I daresay they were plumper than those from Kingdom of Dumpling down the street. Mmm, more delicious porky filling. We were both really impressed with the flavor of the soup noodles, and all three items were really fantastic.

As longtime devotees of Kingdom of Dumpling (and Kingdom of Noodle) I have to say that we both thought this place was better, based on what we've eaten so far. Even the housemade hot sauce was reminiscent of KoD, but a little bit more flavorful IMO. Looking forward to going back and trying more.

I think one of the cooks used to work for Kingdom of Noodle--anyways, she was very friendly and the food came out quick. 

Order the noodle soups, you won't regret it!
author: Bri Y.

description: Chinese restaurants usually get fewer stars than they deserve because of the lack of service but this place has awesome noodles and dumplings and pancakes. Enough said.
author: Shis Z.

description: The worst service ever!!!  We placed an order for chicken dumplings and they never told us that they ran out. We had to ask them what happened to our order. We then asked to substitute for another type of dumpling and they came back 5min later telling us they can't give us an order because there are too many customers waiting to be seated. Our kids did not get to eat since they were waiting for their order.  This is place is so inconsiderate when it comes treating customers.  I would not recommend coming here, there are so many other better dumpling places on Taraval.
author: Corinna L.

description: One of my fav restaurants. If there is a wait, def worth it! Every dish I have ever ordered has been way beyond good. And if you get Joe as your server, best service ever! :) I have lots of friends who visit the city, and the place I bring them to is here. Favorite dishes are the xingjiang pan chicken, dumplings, & for dessert their sweet pancake!!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Very tasty and authentic Chinese food! I come here for their hand-pulled noodles and cold noodle. Their dumplings are absolutely amazing too. Can't find anything bad.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
This review is primarily for their service and hand pulled noodle dish.

This place is the absolute worst place I have ever gotten food. Even Dragon's City across the street has better service. Waitress was extremely inattentive and our tea wasn't warm at all. 

My boyfriend and I just shared their hand pulled noodle dish (xinjiang noodle) for dinner. I was looking forward to eating it after all the rave reviews about it. I didn't mind that they didn't de-bone the chicken in the dish, (as a typical chinese restaurant wouldn't anyway), but there was some sort of seasoning/dirt/loose bone pieces the chef had used that caused my mouth to hit a brick wall every time I chewed. My boyfriend had observed what was in the dish and there were little round black balls that were completely solid in the middle. Didn't really know what they were. Most asian restaurants don't give a crap if there is anything wrong with the dish so we didn't bother asking for another one. We ended up eating what we could and taking home the rest, only to further examine that the chef probably had used some huge 'star anise' seasoning, which might have made it difficult to eat. It literally tasted like there were rocks in my mouth. In terms of flavor, the xinjiang noodle was alright, nothing spectacular.

I suppose the other dishes on the menu are just as great, but I have yet to try. I'm sorry but this experience really ruined it for me and I don't think I will be going back here.
author: Amanda S.

description: I wish I could give this place a higher rating.  We live very close by and have tried it a number of times since they opened years ago.  Early on, the food was pretty good but the service at that time was terrible (incorrect orders, long wait times).  Over time, the service got better, but the food has suffered.  Out of the last 6 times we have eaten or ordered take-out from here, more than half the time the food was terrible - no flavor, bland and inconsistent textures.  Every once in a while, the food is cooked and flavored as it should be, which keeps me coming back to hope the next time will be better.  I wish their food was reliable and consistent!
author: B K.

description: So I called for take out and had to repeat to the lady 4 to 5 times for my order... She said 15-20min. I went there and waited for ANOTHER 15-20min.  Got home. She got half my orders wrong. I went back and wanted refund, instead she goes thru the order and says that we ordered that. I said I wanted pork with green bell pepper, she gave me dumplings...insisting that I ordered dumplings when I repeated 4 times to her PORK WITH GREEN BELL PEPPER. I remembered for a reason. Honestly if they just provided some kind of customer service I would've let it go. But she didn't even apologize that she did t wrote down the correct dish. If you can't speak or don't u understand English....hand it to someone who can or just don't work there.
author: Linda C.

description:
We did not have a problem with service. Food was good and fresh. The peanut based chili sauce was good, with a lot of kick. Go for the dumplings and noodle soup, like in kung fu panda. And go early. It's really busy starting at 6PM.
Make sure you went to the bathroom before heading there
Will  I come back? YES
author: Jean-Yves F.

description:
TL;DR - "Fuck, I should have went to McDonalds."

My biggest complaint was the Xinjiang Style noodles, a family-style dish with zero sharing capabilities.

So the noodles arrive, and I was thinking "this is not looking that tasty. Whatever, it might taste better than it looks." So I'm trying to get myself some noodles here and my hand is literally sky high trying to pull these noodles apart. Whatever, not a problem, I will put this bitch down on my plate first and try to slowly pull it out of pile. Oh come on, are you serious? It's not budging and it's all tangled up inside. "Fuck it. I am trying to eat tonight. I am just going to cut it." Bitch. Please. If I knew it was going to be that difficult to just get these thick chewy sauce-lubricated noodles on my plate before even getting to eat it, then I would have not even ordered it.  It was not easy cutting those noodles with a ceramic spoon, I will tell you that. Whatever, the climb is over and I can finally eat. 

"Fuck, I should have went to McDonalds."


We ordered the two following:
Pork Dumpings with Green Chives
Xinjiang Style (Beef)

Our total came out to $15. On the way out, I saw this other table (who was there before I came) order the same exact noodles and it was untouched. Hmm... I wonder why. Bottom line is, they don't really put enough thought into what the serve and how they serve it. That's not a problem if your food tasted great! I have been to the dirtiest hole-in-the-walls, but at least those places compensated everything else with the taste of their food.

Oh, and one more thing, my girlfriend got diarrhea.
author: Douglas M.

description: It has been a long time since I had a satisfying bold of noodles. Really tasty and at a reasonable price. The service is a little unorganized, but generally friendly vibes.
author: Ken T.

description:
Everytime I'm standing outside of Hot Pot Garden while waiting for a table, I stare across the street wondering.. "WTF IS A HANDCRANKED NOODLE??" This past Wednesday, I finally found out.  Ohhh fresh hand-pulled noodles.. gotcha!

This tiny place has potential to become a hidden gem after some improvement.  My friend and I walked in at 7:30pm on a Wednesday to a full house. Luckily a large group was finishing up and we were able to snag a table. Unfortunately, it took about 10 minutes for someone to get the table ready.  There are 2 waitresses and an older man who seems to be the owner/manager.  All three were very friendly, but my only complaint is that both girls seemed waaaay too flustered and definitely did not know how to prioritize duties-chickens running with their heads off.  For example, while taking a tables' order, the table next to them interrupted and asked for water. The waitress immediately left to get water without completing the tables' order and seemed to have forgetten about them for a few minutes.  I went back tonight and service was horrible.  This time there were two waiters who were nowhere to be seen unless they were bringing food out or to clean a table. When they did come out, they didn't bother to look around.  It took forever to get our tea refilled,  which was never very hot.  When we got our refilled teapot, the guy was so lazy that he climbed over a chair and stretch over to put the teapot on the table. Wtf?!

My friend and I ordered the chicken and spinach dumplings, beef pancake, and combo spicy noodles. Let me tell you, this was way too much for the both of us. 

-combo spicy noodles: 3.5 stars thick "handcranked" noodles in a spicy broth with chicken, pork, and seafood.  The noodles were perfectly cooked and weren't mushy. Warning:these noodles are looooong. I see a lot of complaints about the noodles being extremely long, but chinese hand pulled noodles are supposed to be long. Simply ask for a pair of scissors. The broth had the perfect amount of spice but there was not enough broth and had a crazy amount of noodles. By the time we were done with our meal, the bowl looked untouched. This is definately a bowl full of gluten that will make you stuffed to your neck.

Chicken and spinach dumplings: 3 stars. Nicely filled steamed dumplings. They can be plain without sauce, which the waitress forgot to bring to us. They had the perfect ratio of spinach to chicken.

Beef pancake: 4 stars. Yum! A tasty beef patty stuffed inside of a dough then panfried to perfection. Crispy on the outside, meaty on the inside.  I'd give it 5 stars if they werent so greasy.

Tonight we had the shanghai pork pao (soup dumplings) and blackbean with pork noodles. You get 6 dumplings for $4.95. They were mediocre, nothing to rave about.  The blackbean noodles seem to a popular item. The noodles were perfectly al dente, but none of us were too fond of the flavor.

Parking can be hard since there are a few restaurants along the next couple blocks.  Try to get there right before 6 so you can grab the parking meters. 

CASH ONLY. Total bill came out to be $26 after tax and tip.
author: Cheryl Q.

description: Great meal for an awesome price. The shanghai dumplings are some of the best I've had and the owners take great pride in their food
author: Lindsey K.

description: I lived at Shan dong for 18 years but They still got one of the best dumplings I ever had. The dumpling chef is amazing. She came from a small city in Shan dong and knows exactly the authentic formula!!
author: Ye Y.

description: IF I COULD GIVE A ZERO I WOULD! I went there with my friend and there were 2 tables that weren't cleaned. So we waited, after 10 mins, they still not cleaned. The waiter just ignored and walked pass us when we asked them how long we have to wait. She went straight to other customers and didn't even care to look at us. This is the worst experience I ever had and we left after standing there for 10 mins. Their customer service is horrible, I do not reccomend going because they don't even treat their customers right. Why spend money in a restaurant that doesn't care about their customers? I rather starve then go in that place again!
author: Andy L.

description: The spicy beef noodles are REALLY good! I feel like it is their signature dish here. They just recently opened this year and the noodles are homemade in the back. The pork and corn dumplings are pretty good too. There is a good amount of meat and corn where the dumpling is not too doughy. Service is good, parking isn't too bad. This place is small so make sure to come early and get a table. They take cash and credit :)
author: Nancy Y.

description:
I will admit, I only tried this place because the line for Kingdom of Dumpling down the street was out the door. BEST DECISION EVER. This place is clean, service was excellent and the food was stellar. Chewy, hot savory noodles in a refreshing spicy broth with beef and mushrooms were the starter. Upon gulping that down, we tried the dumplings next- beef, pork with nappa cabbage and pork with chive. The owners work behind the counter and churn out piping hot fresh food. 

Our host/waiter was super -engaging and friendly. He even took a picture of us for his guest wall. When we first walked in, we were seated in the very back because it was so crowded. As people started to trickle out, he offered us a better table with squishy chairs that felt like sneakers (in a good way). 

Shandong Deluxe is clean, the food is fresh and the service is friendly. Not something I can typically say about the average Chinese restaurant. I highly recommend going here and busting a gut. Your wallet won't suffer and you'll waddle out stuffed to the gills with delectable delights.
author: JiEun J.

description:
Wow, this place is divisive.  

I've eaten here about 5 times now.   I have to admit that the woman who runs the show is not a good waitress, almost comically so... but I've never had a 'real' problem with her.  She has bumped into us a number of times.  

I am more interested in the food anyway. 

No one is mentioning the lamb skewers.  I love these.  They taste almost exactly like lamb skewers I had somewhere in Yunan.   
The Xinjian diced chicken dish is expensive, but a huge amount of food not meant for 1 or even 2 people.   Tons of not too dry chicken, potatoes in a super flavorful sauce. Not spicy, but a little on the numbing side.  Plus big hunks of ginger, tons of whole garlic cloves and star anise.  (To Amanda S.  You don't eat the star anise!  And those black balls were peppercorns.)

We've tried, i think, 4 of the dumplings.  Favorite so far is the regular old pork and chives.   I see they have a listing for mackerel dumplings. That sounds crazy.

Also tried the "Beef Pancake". I really enjoyed this. It was not thin. Half inch thick maybe. Seemed to be made from layers of dough and ground beef. The irregularity of the thickness of the dough was a plus in my book. The best part was that it was fried to a crisp on the outside yet quite juicy on the inside. Yet another large portion. My friend commented that it tasted oddly European. I've had various kinds of Chinese beef pies over the years, and these were quite distinct. 

The Xinjiang noodle dish is a bit odd though.  VERY mildly flavored.  (not just water and tomato sauce as someone said) but pretty mild.  The lamb was good though. Not chewy.  The texture of the noodles was great, but you have to be into firm noodles.  I saw someone refer to them as shoelaces.  If all your used to is soggy limp noodles, these are going to seem reallllly firm.  Mine were not cold.

Look past the funky service and get some good and rather unique Chinese food.
author: howard t.

description:
I told Hubby we've been in this place before, when it used to be a Japanese restaurant.  Remnants of that restaurant are still visible with the picture of a Japanese woman and the one arm waving cats lining the counter.  Hubby's a sucker for reviews in the newspaper.  It was jammed at 11:30 AM for a table on Saturday.  We waited about 30 mins for a table for 2.

The waitress barely spoke English.  She took our order and some how managed to misunderstand what we wanted or mixed it up with another order. She wrote down 6 orders and only when the Shao Lung Bao arrived did we realized something wasn't right & we told her we didn't order that.  A waiter popped out (improvement in the English comprehension dept) and said it was alright and took the dumplings back inside.

We tried:
1. Pork/Napa cabbage dumplings - was OK, not great.  I think the dumplings at King of Dumplings and another restaurant on Irving St are better.  Came with about 10 of them, the covering was overcooked and started to fall apart when you tried to pick one up w/your chopsticks.
2. Chicken chow mein - handpulled noodles were good, Only tiny bits of chicken, lots of cabbage, green onions.  The texture of the noodles were good, still oily but not in puddles or lakes at least.
3. Onion pancake - not fried crispy enough for my taste.  Decent and passable.
4. Beef wrap. Now, the author of the article in the SF Chronicle 96 Hrs section (10/3-10/6/13) said it contends with the House of Pancake across the street.  We found basically Hoisin flavored chopped beef with cilantro and cucumber wrapped in a Chinese type tortilla and pan-fried.  The insides were still cold.
